I can't say I parsed the movie with critical intent.  But what I saw was interesting. The acting was good, the special effects very good. Of course, the movie was based on the book so it had to follow the narrative line set there, especially since I believe the screenplay was partly the work of its author, Ms. Collins. My problem with all these futuristic movies is that there is much too much technological input. The bit about sponsors being able to send what look like drones to help their favorites is brilliant. On the other hand, the deux ex machina of firings, rockets, explosions and penetrating this and that shield just becomes  tedious after a while without the proper setup. I believe, like Hitchcock said, you have to engage the audience. If the audience can't see the A of a plot to kill B then B walking into the trap means nothing except a lot of sudden jolts. Also, the concei/metaphor must be consistent, and viable. The general idea of a Hunger Games, and the like is very interesting and resonates accordingly. Even the notion that we are watched as by some omniscient God, as our heroine and her associates are, is credible and interesting. I'll even accept interventions such as flooding the field with some degree of realism. After all, Poseidon wasn't above stirring up the ocean if you insulted him, Athena wasn't above getting piqued and causing mayhem if she was not properly respected, and God wasn't averse to parting the Red Sea when required. But neither of them pressed buttons to jumpstart the narrative.  And there were too many of these disjunctive maneuvers in this film which became as boring as Avatar was to me. Too much sound and fury in the end signifies nothing but laziness; and it becomes tiresome. Id rather see people stranded on an island with only their wits to survive than so much techno craft and mumbo jumbo. Nonetheless, despite so many of these broad strokes, the movie did move apace and was entertaining. I agree with some reviewers that the story has been told before with more subtlety, but after all, even Shakespeare was not averse to underscoring some of his concerns about morality. The movie is worth a view, for sure. Whether it carries an emotional wallop is another story.

Catching fire is the second in the Hunger Games trilogy. I liked the first film but, not having read the books, feared the second one would get mired down in the feigned love relationship between Katness and Peeta. It didn't. The story begins in District 12 where they are preparing to leave their family and friends again on a "Victor's Tour" of the districts. Just before leaving, Katness is visited by president Snow who reveals that her act of rebellion in the games has encouraged unrest in the districts. If she doesn't convince everyone that it was not rebellion but blind love for Peeta that guided her actions, her family, friends and the district will pay the price. But a Victors' Tour is just the beginning of a new nightmare as President Snow announces the 75th Annual Hunger Games (The Quarter Quell) - a competition that will pit the victors of prior games against each other.

While Catching fire is a great action adventure drama, it is also a commentary on economic inequality and its consequences. But offers hope in the courage of young people willing to oppose the savagery that keeps them enslaved.

The second movie in the Hunger Games series is really well-done.  As an avid fan of the books, I was really impressed at what a masterful job the director did of capturing the essence of the book on film, which can't be easy to do with all of the complicated plot points and futuristic elements.

Katniss Everdeen survived her first time in the hunger games arena, but in doing so, she has infuriated the President, who feels that he has embarrassed him and made a mockery of the games.  As punishment, he devises a way to send her back into the hunger games arena a second time. But this time, she is determined to ensure that Peeta is the sole survivor.

Excellent acting, beautiful costumes, and terrific sets make this a terrific movie!

I love how the movie illustrates Katniss' struggle between her old life (Gale) and her new life (Peeta). I don't recall that effort or distinction in the book. She can never be who she was prior to her Hunger Games no matter how much she wishes things could go back to where they were.  Peeta's development into her quiet strength is remarkable and it's beautiful how she slowly discovers just that: Peeta is her rock because he gets it. Great movie.

Jennifer Lawrence, who seems to be in just about every other movie made in the last two years, returns as Katniss Everdeen in this second 'Hunger Games' installment and she is every bit as good as she was in the first one.
Lawrence, who has surprising range for a young actress, in fact plays the emotionally conflicted Katniss perfectly. I've tried, but I just can't imagine anyone else in this role. There are other actors who could match her physicality and some who might be able to match her emotional range but I can't think of anyone who could combine them in the way that she seems to do so effortlessly.
She isn't the only one who nails her role in this lavish dystopian film, however. Donald Sutherland as the evil President Snow, for example,  brings exactly the right level of intense malevolence to the role. The late Philip Seymour Hoffman, in one of his last roles, is excellent as the new game master who has an agenda of his own, and Josh Hutcherson plays Peeta as though he was born into the role. Woody Harrelson, Elizabeth Banks and Liam Hemsworth also stand out in this remarkable movie.
If you liked 'The Hunger Games' then this movie is something you must see.

The movie got off to a very slow start, with the pacing in the first half of the movie not matching the second half. This made it difficult to get into. The romance portion of the movie, especially, felt a little flat. If the fist half had been edited to have quicker pacing that was more consistent with the second half, it would have been a much stronger film.

Overall worth watching if you are a fan of the series or have nothing better to watch.
Much better than the 1st movie.  This one actually was better than the 2nd book.  Better interaction of characters and a better "feel" of the why the actions of the characters.

Tighter than the first, nice enough production values, and has a great stand out in Jena Malone, but the marginalization of Hutcherson (the best part of the first movie), the wasting of Philip Seymour Hoffman, the relatively limited palate of Jennifer Lawrence's performance (mostly numb or ugly-crying), and the general sense of trying to avoid its own premise drag it down to pretty good.  Somehow made me appreciate the book more, but I don't mean that as a slam - it helped fill in some ill fitting imaginative holes in the text.

Love Jennifer Lawrence in anything but this nonsense.  As a Veteran trained for guerrilla warfare believe me folks anyone as emotional as this character would be the first and easiest victim.  This is choreographed CGI madness where a Warrior would lose control emotionally over and over in the midst of other professional warriors/killers is ludicrous.  This is just another series representing the prostitution of Hollywood screen writers in a tired exercise of remaking the same movie three times + for ten year old girls. Yes, in an era of the future tech a Bow and Arrow is a master weapon?  Nonsense!

Nowadays, everything filmed for the preteen audience seems to must have 3 or more of the same idea over and over.  Jennifer and the Writers/Producers are laughing all the way to the bank I guess. If I owned the Bluray I'd loved to count the number of times she loses her emotions and control and somehow none of these pro's take advantage but in reality that may work at hunting squirrels but not professional warrior killers that keep centered and in control. Is the Defense Dept watching and taking notes so they may bring back archery to battle ISIS? What utter nonsense!  When I see the 3rd movie trailers of her shooting a moving aircraft out of the sky with an arrow that is simply ridiculous to think anyone could make an arrow move at that velocity and height.  Just CGI B.S.!

These "Hunger Games" films actually leave me a little cold, to be honest.  The set pieces are great, the action solid, but the performances are wildly uneven, from excellent to completely overdrawn and melodramatic.  It's like some of the actors are in a different movie.  That said, Donald Sutherland, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Lynn Cohen, Woody Harrelson, Jeffrey Wright and even Lenny Kravitz deliver nicely understated yet powerful portrayals.  And Jennifer Lawrence carries the film with a performance that always hits the right notes, never too big or small.  Quite an accomplishment in a film that paints mostly in broad and obvious strokes.

It was a good movie, but the ending was kind of a drop off point.  That being said, I never read any of the books, so I don't know how well it coincided with them.

Through out the movie I kept asking myself why the producers didn't let Suzanne Collins help write the screen play? There are many points in the film that I felt that the dialogue was a bit "ham-fisted" and sparse on character's motivations. The movie seemed to me to be the Reader's Digest version of the Abridged version of the book.

I would suggest reading the book rather than seeing this movie. But even the book seemed like there were many parts edited out to keep the page count down. Middle books are always toughest to write because they are to transition the reader (or movie goer) to the next stage of the story. As an example, The Empire Strikes Back.

Lastly, it seemed to me that Jennifer Lawrence was just phoning in this performance. I really didn't see any of the internal struggles of Katniss in her eyes or body language. Katniss was determined to give up all for Peeta but yet it was all the others sacrificing themselves for her. Jennifer Lawrence couldn't seem to translate that internal struggle to the screen.

If you are really bored, then watch this film... though it will only make you less bored.

I never read the last two books of this series and probably never will. So this review is just based on the film as it stands by itself apart from the book.

The first movie The Hunger Games caught my interest because of lead actress Jennifer Lawrence. And she continues to do a great job portraying the character Katniss. It was nice to see the late Philip Seymour Hoffman in this second film to give it star power which I don't think it needed considering the popularity of the books to draw in fans of all types. But that's Hollywood politics which I know nothing about.

Though the concept of the books of which the movies are based is nothing new it is sort of a refreshing take on it. For something in it's genre watch the Japanese film Battle Royale which was released over a decade ago.

The movie's pacing starts off well and ends well. Throughout the whole movie you are kept at the edge of your seat and in suspense as it takes you on a ride through yet another survival ordeal. There are neat new threats of course and watching them deal with their predicaments as corny or over the top it may appear at times is still entertaining.

It's not a bad movie if you're not looking for Lawrence of Arabia or Schindler's List or a Lincoln type film. Sure there are many better action/drama films out there but it keeps it's entertainment value and is worth renting the first time on instant video. I liked it enough I bought the first two movies on instant video.

I read all three books as well as Suzanne Colins other series, Gregor the Overlander. He writing style is tedious and her character development is week. Her plot is decent and she has a timely and fascinating underlying dilemma and themes. She seems particularly interested in children in war or warlike situations. With what's going on around or world I found the themes and central dilemma strong enough to pull me through her stories, but they aren't high on my list of great writing. But different medias have different strengths. This movie Shines! It is exceedingly rare for a movie to improve on a book; this one Does! Jennifer Lawrence takes a very flaky described character and builds a dynamic and believable young woman. Plot and theme are more important in film than character arc. As such, though Divergent was my preference in book, Hunger Games had been my movie preference. You'll love the movie, but if it inspires you to pick up the book, be warned that you might be disappointed. My sister only read to the end of the first book at my provocation that the themes and dilemma were worth the read. She flatly refused the second book. But she had loved the movies right along with me.

All sequels  face the same problem. Introducing a new premise for a story in the first episode is exciting, but how do you duplicate that thrill in the sequels? As far as writing goes, the only options are 1) to up the ante for the protagonists and 2) to tighten the screws on the innocent victims. That makes all sequel story lines predictable and less compelling.

Since we know there are more books remaining in the series, it  was a pretty good bet Katniss would not get killed off in this episode. So the only choices the writers had were to make President Snow even more despicable, make the oppression worse, and to create even more fiendish games. (I wrote the premise for this series in a short story for a creative writing class at Mizzou in 1969. I'm glad to see it come of age). Nice cinematography, nice work with the costumes and sets. Lovely group of actors. The popcorn was excellent. I made it myself.

Overall I thought this movie was reasonably entertaining, especially if you have not read the books. It dispenses with the annoying shaky-cam cinematography of the first movie, but somehow it managed to be an even more shallow adaptation than the first movie. Specific instances of the Capitol's cruelty and abuse were simply skimmed over and quite a lot of Katniss' personal agency was simply scrubbed away. Unfortunately I felt Phillip Seymour Huffman's performance in this film was simply weak and the behind-the-scenes-at-the-capitol material didn't deliver. I think Jennifer Lawrence could do a fantastic job if she was given better material in these films and she really killed her few really personal scenes.

I devoured the books and was excited to see the movie versions.  It was hard to imagine how they could do the books justice in film.  In my estimation, I believe this movie was well done.  Many scenarios that my mind's eye had difficulty seeing were amazingly created.  I loved the non stop action and the level of tension that was ever present.  Casting is great although I missed the woman who played the original activity coordinator (gold hair).  The abrupt ending has me waiting anxiously to see the final book in movie form.

It's hard to keep a movie so close to the book as this one is. Sure, some minor things are left out or tweaked a little to keep the movie a reasonable length. As with the book, you need to have seen or read the first story to fully understand what is going on, it is not a stand alone. It is a trilogy and you will want all three parts. The story is well written, has good characters that keep you entertained, well acted, good set and costumes, good effects, and good direction as well as well edited. This movie and The Hunger Games managed to maintain the look feel and sensation of this wonderful literary series.  Of course there were some elements that were cut as needed to allow for smoother movie flow but in truth I cannot say how impressed I was with the level of detail and effort put forth for this amazing movie.  It would have been so easy to cut corners but it is so obvious that the film makers did not.  Since I have seen both "The Hunger Games," and "Catching Fire," I know I will be amazed by what is to follow.  It saddens me that Seymor's presence in the next movie will be computer generated.  I know the producers, directors and writers will do everything in their power to see that his memory is honored posthumously.  I am a great fan of this literary series and am so grateful that Miss Collins saw fit to share it with us, the world.

Thank you to you Miss Collins and to those who worked with you to bring this work to the silver screen.  Your choices in actors, sets, costuming, portrayals, music, props and characterizations were all so vividly close to the narrative fiction of the writing that I was allowed to feel the desperation of the Hunger Games from the perspective of District 12, which incidentally is where my original family routes spring from.

Thank you so very much for this experience.

For fans of the books this will seem a more faithful interpretation than the first movie. Yes, there are deviations but the overall "feel" is more serious and less--much less-- teen romance. Also, the pace is much faster.

Bear in mind, I have not read the books, so I'm basing my opinion on the strength of the story told in the film, without comparison to the books.

Catching Fire continues the saga of this dystopian society and their perverse love of the Hunger Games, in which people die until there is only one left. Well, yes, a familiar scenario, born in the Games of ancient Rome, and probably even before that.

I don't want to give it away, so I will simply state that the story picks up what seems barely weeks after the end of the first film, so good continuity here. Our heroes are on tour, celebrating their victory and learning that it is not what they expected it would be. But they "go along", in spite of their misgivings... as if they even had a choice.

What transpires is somewhat expected, but not for the reasons you might think. And that is smart. And the film moves forward without lumbering or becoming particularly tedious, another plus. The story is well told, and the undercurrent is well executed and ever present throughout, also a good thing. It is well acted, regardless of what you may think of the lead actor outside her performances.

The four stars is due to some predictability, perhaps because we know the outcome - or at least we THINK we know the outcome - which doesn't reach its inevitable conclusion in quite the way we thought, which is a good thing.

Now, as long as they don't blow the final two part conclusion (think how they completely destroyed the Matrix trilogy before the end of the second film, rendering the third film equally unwatchable), this now four film saga will be among the better science fiction sagas to come down the pike in a very long time.

And that, indeed, is something I anticipate with great joy.

Guys please stop giving a rip off from multiple original ideas 5 stars. The author of this book ripped off battle royale put it in to her book, then sprinkled some of her ideas in.
I cant "technically" call this plagiarism because of the slightly different settings and slight differences like the relationship of the characters but anybody who watches the movie with half a brain can obviously see that hunger games is nothing original.

I gave it 2 stars because i take thievery seriously, and the original creator of this idea Koushun Takami the author of battle royale worked on this it took him decades of his life to work on that book, to say the least He worked hard on it. and here comes Kollins ripping it off.
Whats worse is i see major websites like business insider, writing articles that point out very small differences of the two books/movies.

So remember guys if you can find a good idea from a foreign country just copy it and change somethings around and you got yourself a novel. and thieves will gather all around and philosophise on how its not stolen

As usual, stunning visuals, outstanding costuming and great effects.  My one complaint with this movie is that Jennifer Lawrence is so bad in the first half of the movie I can hardly stand it.  Katniss comes off as pouting, selfish, and spoiled during the tour rather than a young women who is desperate to save her family and friends.  By the time we are in training and then in the arena, things seem back to normal and she does a brilliant job of portraying Katniss.  The other acting is really well done, but let's face it, Lawrence has to carry the cast and for the first half of the movie, she just doesn't.

Still it's a great rental, especially while it's free on Prime and a great way to "prep" for watching the new movie which comes out soon. Hope you enjoy!

Jennifer Lawrence brings the reluctant heroin of this dystopian series alive, displaying the full range of emotions one would expect of an young lady caught in the vice of world changing events. The story, itself a profound reflection on a future we may be hurtling toward unaware, is prophetic in the old definition of the word: it's a cautionary tale of what happens when people crushed under tyranny reach the breaking point. Having read the books, I can tell you the movies were surprisingly loyal to the author's vision, and this second part of the trilogy is full of as much tension, drama and excitement as the first.

Admittedly, Lawrence was the scene stealer for me, though it was the supporting case that made her role seem so smooth and effortless. As movies are a team accomplishment, I offer kudos to all involved. And I'll be keeping my eye on Lawrence, a young lady who promises to be the type of actress that can disappear into her role as easily as Charlize Theron, and who offers a strong, independent role model in her real life as well. This is one of the handfull of movies I'll be able to watch over and over again through years and still enjoy.

Of course you'd need to see Hunger Games before Catching Fire. I do notice a change in directing styles between the 'Hunger Games' director Ross / crew and 'Catching Fire' director Lawrence / crew, a disappointment was director Lawrence's mess-up of Effie Trinket's wardrobe: overdone? (yes in Effie's character), high fashion? (no, the gaudy designs were amateur), and her brainless capitol nuance self was killed in the mis-directed reaping of victors scence. Despite her sympathy for Katniss in the book, she would always present her haughty-self (manners!), or for comic relief Effie could have tripped on the stairs, the hiss at the laughing crowd. Lawrence blew it. Also, the three-fingered support starting with Katniss' mom seemed contrived. In comparison, the first Hunger Game reaping scene is classic.

Scrutinizing the IMAX screen view used throughout the arena scenes, My Sony BDP-S360 blue ray player with the latest version 14 update shows additional view using the full sceen height on my 1080p screen, but the arena clock's circumfrence occupies nearly the entire width of my screen versus Amazon Prime arena widescreen shows ample greenery on each side of the 'clock'. At times, I prefer not losing the widesceen horizontal view vs. gaining vertical info, example: the beach kissing scene. Like many blue ray movies, the IMAX views are pseudo IMAX, a true IMAX screen shows extra vertical view without expense of the horizontal view. I'm assume that my blue ray player update is up to the task, but blue ray playback standards might NOT be standard. Also, IMAX theater screens are likely not sized proportional to home HDTV's.

The revolution ramps up and the mockingjay revolutionaries come together at high levels to fight the brutal dictatorship in this well done 2nd installment. Katniss is more brooding than ever and Peeta has grown up as their relationship becomes complicated. This film does a great job of completing the first movie and setting up the 3rd. Recommended.

Fantastic movie.  Amazing character portrayal, superior computer graphics and Suzanne Collins' story bursts onto the screen with a vengeance in the second of the three Hunger Games installments.  Loved it all.  I would recommend it to anyone over the age of 12 due the nature of the material and some violent content, although some mature pre-teens might be ok with it.  I would advise parents to pre-screen it for themselves.  The acting on all accounts is superb.  If you have not seen "Hunger Games", then I would recommend seeing that first to get the backstory before watching Catching Fire.  And, it goes without saying (although I am saying it), watch "Mockingjay" to complete this series.

They get 3 stars for a perfect quality DVD and then -1 stars for the digital copy.

The digital copy is trash. Ultraviolet has changed their policy since the original Hunger Games movie came out. Apparently, Ultraviolet no longer allows for iTunes movie downloads. Instead, you can make an account for Ultraviolet AND one for one of their licensed outlets, download it through both services, then either download an app or get a SD copy on your computer (even for HD movies). THEN you can watch your movie.

There you go, Ultraviolet...discourage movie piracy by having people who buy digital copies jump through a thousand damn hoops to get their movie. Absolutely brilliant.

"The Hunger Games: Catching Fire" is excellent! This is how the story goes: Katniss Everdeen has returned home safely after winning the 74th Annual Hunger Games along with fellow tribute Peeta Mellark. Winning means that they must turn around and leave their family and close friends, embarking on a "Victor's Tour" of the districts. Along the way, Katniss senses that a rebellion is simmering, but the Capitol is still very much in control as President Snow prepares the 75th Annual Hunger Games (The Quarter Quell), a competition that could change Panem forever.

The cast led by Jennifer Lawrence (terrific as usual as Katniss Everdeen), Josh Hutcherson (as Peeta Mellark), Liam Hemsworth (as Gale Hawthorne), Woody Harrelson (as Haymitch Abernathy), Elizabeth Banks (as Effie Trinket), Lenny Kravitz (as Cinna), Philip Seymour Hoffman (as Plutarch Heavensbee), Jeffrey Wright (as Beetee), Stanley Tucci (as Caesar Flickerman) & Donald Sutherland (as President Snow) is excellent. The directing by Francis Lawrence is excellent. The screenplay (based on Suzanne Collins' novel, who also executive produced the film) by Simon Beaufoy & Michael deBruyn is excellent.

The music by James Newton Howard is excellent. The cinematography by Jo Willems is excellent. The film editing by Alan Edward Bell is excellent. The casting by Debra Zane is excellent. The production design by Philip Messina is excellent. The art direction by John Collins, Adam Davis & Robert Fechtman is excellent. The set decoration by Larry Dias, set designs by Alan Au, Jim Hewitt, George Lee, Karl J. Martin, Sheila Nash, Harry E. Otto & Easton Michael Smith, set dressings by Sam Carter, Mark Keever, Steven Ladish, Chris Larsen, Drew Meyers, Jason Negron, Ky Hoang Nguyen, Tripp Norton & Allyson Petty is excellent. The costume design by Trish Summerville is excellent. The special make-up effects by Ve Neill, Steve Winsett & Erin Draney is excellent. The stunts coordinated by Chad Stahelski & Sam Hargrave is excellent. The special effects coordinated by Steve Cremin is excellent. The visual effects coordinated by Joanie Croteau, Chad Hudson, Vanessa Joyce, Eunice Khoo, Anouk L'Heureux, Martine Losier, Karina Mariano, Daniel Matley, Jessica Newhouse-Smith, Carol-Ann Ouimet, Laetitia Seguin & Adrian Steel, supervised by Paul Butterworth, Adrian De Wet, Thierry Delattre, Matt Dessero, Francois Dumoulin, Jeffrey Kalmus, Richard Martin, Stephane Naze, Janek Sirrs, Philippe Theroux, Marc Varisco & Guy Williams is excellent.

This is an excellent and well-crafted movie that is entertaining and intriguing. This is also an excellent sequel that is better than its original. Jennifer Lawrence, again, gives another terrific performance as Katniss Everdeen. Francis Lawrence takes over in the role of direction in place of the original's Gary Ross with excellence. This is one of the best movies of the last winter season and of last year, as well.

I was glued to this movie from start to finish, like the first.  This movie is so true to life, in a lot of ways.  You have the people wanting to revolt against the 1%, but they need something, someone to believe in.  In this case, the warrior, hero, and savior is in the form of a female - Katniss Everdeen.  She's still finding herself, as she hasn't quite come into her power yet.  In this movie she's still naive.  Again, this is one of those movies, where you have an evil dictator manipulating and controlling those around him, or trying to.  He's very insecure, and he knows the people are restless and that his time is up.

Filmed in Hawaii, this game, the 3rd-25th anniversary game, has new rules.  Katniss and her allies see patterns and tries to adapt to them, but the game master is in control and controls the game.  You have scary fog that kills, killer monkey-like creatures and more.  I was disappointed that the movie stopped where it did, but I would imagine that this movie could have easily turned into 4 hours instead of 2 and a half, so I understand why the movie stopped where it did, but it doesn't take away my frustration for closure or a clean ending - URGH!

Now I have to wait for Part III.

That means I will have to see it at the theater.

I'd rate this just below 4 stars if I could (3.8) primarily due to the shaky-cam style production. I absolutely hate that method of capturing feature films. I can take a little of it when the need is there, but come on guysget a TRIPOD! In terms of the movie itself, it's a continuation (of course) from the first film and holds up well to the stylistic designs of the first film. I think the acting has improved vs. the original. Blu-ray quality is excellent both visually and aurally, and there are some decent special features. The ultraviolet streaming version looks pretty good in HDX (top quality) if your home's Internet connection is fast enough to deliver it. Otherwise, it's okay, but doesn't come close to the blu-ray in quality.

You can see why it went so quickly from theater to DVD.  I guess if you are around 12 it would be the best thing ever, but having read the book I thought it stunk! The plot is poorly developed, the acting was wooden, and if you hadn't read the book you wouldn't have any idea what was going on.
Okay, in all fairness, there were some good points.  But why suddenly introduce the extreme amount of coolness between Katness and Peeta.  That was barely alluded to in the first film but, whoa, they hate each other in this film?  What's up with that?  And this film implies that Katness had two lovers, Peeta and Gale.  The book makes this much clearer.  The relationship with Gale was strong but they were not lovers. Also the relationship with Petta was more like gradual acceptance.  She does not suddenly take him to bed  The kissing with Gale and taking Petta to bed is too confusing. It happens in the book but in a much difference context. The sudden takeover of district 12 was also much clearer in the book.  The scenes in the arena make no sense and even though we know there's another movie in the trilogy what kind of ending was that?  The gamemaker is suddenly on the good side?  And the comment by Haymitch, "That's why we don't let you make the plans", is in context in the book, but what does it mean in the movie?.
The book "Catching Fire" is excellent, perhaps the best of the three.  It is rich in plot development, the characters, especially Haymitch, are much more real, and the arena makes more sense.

A couple of more comments-
How come the picture of Rue is still on the floor when the book makes it clear it was cleaned up and the writing "Senna Crane' Is barely visible on the dummy.
I agree with President Snow.  Nope!
the story is confused does not make any sense though the actress is very good and the scenes well filmed the story has no grounding is morally disturbing, basically stupid.

This movie was amazing. It was the 7th time I've seen it and it never gets old. I love how it stays so true to the book. The acting is AMAZING,  the visuals and costuming fits perfectly for everyone, and the fact that the movie really sets the tone about rebellion and government is absolutely wonderful. It is such an improvement from the shaky cam disaster that we would call the Hunger Games.  All of these things really support the movie, but the thing that really made the movie what it was was the score. For me, the best pieces was The Fog, especially when they start playing the definitely improved piece called The Reaping from the Hunger Games.  My other favorite would have to be Arena Crumbles.  It is so emotional and it gives me chills every time I hear it. I would definitely recommend listening to them on Youtube. I also love the continuing Katniss theme, The Tour, and Let's Start.

When you're surprised when a movie's end credits roll, you know that was a good movie.  I honestly thought the story would continue after the last scene, and the time spent watching this movie just flew right by.

They fixed the CGI problems from the first movie, and I think all the actors delivered a stronger performance this time around.  I found myself empathizing with Effie Trinket, of all people, and I didn't anticipate that at all.

Really, this is a unique piece of well done dystopic science fiction.  A cautionary tale we all need to watch and think about.
Of course, I loved the books even more (doesn't everyone say that?), but this movie still had me at the edge of my seat.  Can't wait for the final movie to come out!

I loved the first "Hunger Games" & this latest one was even better.  The plot was somewhat different, which made it interesting; not just a repeat of the first installment, & seemed to be more thoughtfully written.  I liked the personal interactions of the characters, as they battled not only each other, but the "system" & what it was doing to their society.  To me, I saw parallels to what is going on in the Middle East, with innocent people suffering at the hands of corrupt leaders.  There is deeper psychological meaning to these movies than may meet the eye of a casual viewer, & I encourage some thoughtful introspection on what you have seen, & how it relates to our world now, & how we interact with one another.  I found it entertaining, suspenseful, & thought provoking.  Loved it.

The first half of the movie was more interesting to me, because it delved much deeper into the politics of the dystopian kingdom of Panem, where a totalitarian central government lords it over the capitol and 12 districts...the mysterious 13th District having been reportedly destroyed. We learn from President Snow (a menacing Donald Sutherland) that there may be a ground swell of rebellion in some of the districts..and that Katniss Everdeen is a source and inspiration for rebellion. So Katniss has to walk on thin ice, so to speak, while carrying on her bogus relationship with Peeta Mallark, and hiding her true feelings for Gale Hawthorne. Yet it appears that no matter how careful she is, her life and those who are nearest to her are still in jeopardy. This is an exceptionally well made follow-up to "The Hunger Games", and is adapted from the second book in the trilogy by Suzanne Collins. Jennifer Lawrence reprises her Katniss Everdeen characterization; and as with all her performances I've seen, she totally immerses herself in the character. Josh Hutcherson and Liam Hemsworth also reprise their characters of Peeta and Gale and do well. Woody Harrelson is back again, perfectly cast as Haymitch; as is Elizabeth Banks as the silly but loyal Effie Trinket. As for new characters, look for Phillip Seymour Hoffman, in a superb performance as the Master of the Games, Plutarch Heavensbee; and Jena Malone as the cunning, Johanna Mason, one of the tributes allied with Katniss and Peeta during the Quarter Quell games, which pits former Hunger Games victors against each other. The movie ends rather abruptly and you'll be left hungering for more...never fear, two more films are planned to portray the events in the third book, "Mockingjay"

I really liked the first one, it was unique, which for this day and age is saying something. I really like lionsgate, I loved the saw movies. I wasn't as impressed with the second one. Thou I did like it. SPOILER ALERT:: I called it from the start of the movie that the guy runing the games was in on the revoluation, the way he was talking to Catness, it just gave it away. My big problems with this movie. I never really beleived that Catness and Petta really loved eachother. In the first one they used his affection for her to try and set them up to kill eachother in the end. However I never really beleived that Catness really had any feeling for Petta it seemed mostly the other way around. I don't like Petta I think he is a 5th wheel. In the first one he had cool como and he was trying to survive on his own, but in this one he is just pathidic. He doesn't have a cool weapon, or any special ability. Catness is the kickass zena warrior with the godly bow, and the amazing quiver that never runs out of arrows. I thought the writers never got a hand of Catness Charecter, in the first part of the movie she was cold, devoted to her orginal bf, and I felt that was more of her charecter, but towards the end she was just a crying, whining, and it was a drastic change that I didn't get into. I felt Jennifer Lawrence was good but the writers never got a strong hold on the charecter. I thought they had a good idea at the start of the movie when Catness accidently killed the guy while hunting was a really good idea. It has the ablity of derailing the whole revaloution, but they never used it. The Pressident could have found out and used it to blackmail her. I hope they don't forget about it for the third movie.

All that said, I did really like the movie. I liked seeing the people fight back. When it comes to a sudden suprise ending with a twist, linonsgate always delivers on that one. I see lionsgate movie and I just expect a crazy twist from someone that sat through all the saw movies. I thought the story was well done, it really did a good job of making you feel for the people, and set up the revolt well. It was exciting and kept you on the edge of your seat, for all around I felt it was well done. I am very excited to see how the third movie is done and how it will end. I hope for a really great ending with a sedistic twist. All around if you liked the first one, I would check this one out.

On the plus side this is a faithful rendition of the book and the cast generally shines again. Jennifer Lawrence is once more breathtaking as Katniss Everdeen. Woody Harrelson (Haymitch), Donald Sutherland (President Snow), Lenny Kravitz (Cinna), Elizabeth Banks (Effie) and Stanley Tucci (Caesar) deliver star power superbly. A nice surprise is Josh Hutcherson upping his game as Peeta.

On the negative side Liam Hemsworth is still a dud as Gale, but mercifully his role is cut versus the books. It is also difficult to see where in the movie they spent the bigger budget. Many of the sets still look amateurish. The biggest negative that the movie cannot overcome however is that this is easily the worst book of the trilogy, especially with the repetition of the first, and as a faithful rendition, the movie is severely encumbered by it.

Overall, I liked this movie.  I really like the Hunger Games trilogy of books, and have been impressed overall with the two movies I've seen, and look forward to the first half of Mockingjay.  The reason I only give it four stars is because I think this version moves too quickly to really develop characters the way that they are in the first book.  I would not have been sorry to have seen Catching Fire broken into two movies, or at least a longer first movie.  It's hard for me to tell if this is only because I have read the book a couple of times and know it well, or whether this is the impression that non-readers of the trilogy will have.

Overall, the cast does a fine job of acting.  This is an entertaining movie, and I recommend it to anyone who likes action movies, dystopian themes, or watching women in a leading role.

I have read the entire series. While different (as expected) the movies stick close enough to be entertaining.  I love the chemistry between Katniss and President Snow! It's not hard to feel the animosity between them.  Gale's character in the movie annoys me almost as much as he did in the books, and Peeta is played very well.  The actors did a superb job making their characters believable and even likeable in their own ways.  There were times when the script slowed the momentum a bit much, which is why I gave it 4/5 stars.

I do have one rather silly thing to point out.  In the first movie, they got Buttercup's  (the cat) color wrong.  I kept thinking; "how hard is it to find a dirty orange-ish cat?" Yeah, I know. It is a goofy thing to get annoyed over, especially when there are other events I initially thought "it didn't happen that way" with.  Then as I was rewatching Catching Fire the other night, I noticed they got the cat right! LOL!

The second in the Hunger Games series seems to vary a bit from the book but really in an excellent rendition--maybe even better than the book. The duplicitous President Snow and the Panem Capital have decided to send the victors of the Hunger Games (promised a life of peace and exclusion from further "tribute") to a special Games in honor of the 75th year. Every 25 years is a "Quarter Quell" and this one is being used to take down Katniss, now the symbol of rebellion.

The action is well-handled, the supporting cast of victors (Mags, "Nuts", "Volts", Johanna and Finnick each are well-cast, well-scripted and make for an exciting ensemble cast.) The character of the new Gamesmaster Plutarch Heavensbee is excellent. The late Philip Seymour Hoffman plays him a bit ambiguously. Is he on the side of Snow, a sadistic creator of impossible-to-win situations, or is he secretly sympathetic with the rebels? He was perfectly cast and it's a shame he died before completing the next film (Mockingjay) though he did shoot a fair number of scenes. A loss of a talented actor.

My only complaint is similar to the one I have now in the trend to serialize novels. It ends on a cliffhanger and of course we're waiting for the next film. I just don't think it makes a standalone film to end on a surprise note and such unfinished business. But never mind, the third film is on the way and I'm certain it will be as good or better than "Catching Fire."

Awesome movie looks fantastic. I like it more than the first one. Probably because it is not an origin story.

I read all the books.  I hated the first movie - too flat, not indicative of the internal dialogue of the characters, blah blah blah.  This one does not have that problem, at all.  Enjoyed it and glad they stuck fairly well to the plot of the book.  Pleasantly surprised.
The DVD was fine. The movie sucked. The first one was a whole lot better. do not buy this movie.

I loved The Hunger Games movie and have read all the books in the series.  I just didn't like Catching Fire as much as The Hunger Games. It's still a very good movie (maybe just a tad bit long though....2+ hours). Am looking forward to the next installment.
It was just as good as the first.. sad to see Phillip Seymour Hoffman..cant wait for the next installment. Love Jennifer Lawrence.

This sequel stands on its own, expect to see a third.

This is a very good movie. It has a surprise ending that really was great. I was not bored or falling asleep through this one. It has a lot of special effects in it and the actresses and actors do a great job in it. Lots of action.
I loved the movie and the book.  I felt the movie did the book justice.  I read the book in November and saw the movie in May, but I believed the movie followed the book closely.

I enjoyed the first movie and was not disappointed here.  The story evolves well even though it does drag a bit in the middle. this movie makes me want to see the next one. it had more of the book in this one. it stayed a bit true to the book. could be a tiny bit more like the book, though.

I'm hoping the third one will be better than the book (of the three novels, I liked the third one least of all). I have added this to my permanent library and will watch it again in the not too distant future.

When this movie first came out, i did not want to see it...it took me a couple  of years to finally break down and watch the hunger games..but  ever since i watched the first one...the Hunger Games..i have been hooked..i have watched both moves several times and can not wait till the 3rd one comes out...

The second movie was better than the first movie. I think it is because it the storyline revolved around more than just the game which was about the last third of the movie. I also appreciate that less of the movie was spent on showing scenes of violence even though there was a lot in the book.  I would recommend this movie more than the first.

I didn't like the first Hunger Games movie very much. The movie is great and deserves at least a four star rating.  My viewing experience was not however as i have high speed internet but some of this movie was streamed below HD quality.  I haven't had this issue with my other streaming services.

Some people obviously do not get the subtext of the books and story at all.  Killing people affects you.  In the books, every victor is psychologically  damaged by the experience.  Haymitch is a drunk, the district 6 victors are addicted to morphling, Johanna is narcissistic as is Finnick, Nuts is a bit crazy, Annie is crazy, others become vicious, etc., etc.

This movie could have done more to underscore that theme.  It is, however, a fairly faithful adaptation of the book, which pleases fans of the franchise.  This book is a transition from the first book, which introduces the world of Panem and sets up the situation that leads to the eventual rebellion in the next two movies.
If you liked the first movie, you'll like the second.  I really enjoyed this.  Read the book that follows it to see what happens.  Can't wait for Mockingjay.

I enjoyed watching this second Hunger Games. Can't really compare it with the first one because it was so long ago that I watched it. Must have liked though or I would not of bought this one. Worth watching

Exactly the same story and scenario as the 1st movie. Nothing new.
Worse: the last scenes of the movie are open-ended... little surprise...

If you read the books, and/or loved the first movie, you are in luck, as this is the first movie all over again. The whole first half of the film is a convoluted plot to get them back in the "games" again, from there on out, it's about the same as the first one.
A movie for teens.  Jennifer is a great actress but there's not much she can do in the film since there's no plot. Just terrible.

the first 40 minutes of the movie WILL put you to sleep. All they do for the first 40 minutes is mope around and talk about how sad they all are...i literally was falling asleep and took the movie OUT of my dvd player and put in something else. Went back another night to finish watching and then, once the movie FINALLY started to pick up there was a re-lapse of more boring scenes!...on a long train ride and the characters were acting all bored like "what are we going to do on this boring long train ride to the capital?" The move was boring, the characters were acting bored cause they *were* and then, as if thats not bad enough we have to listen to all the Victors crying and whining and complaining about not wanting to die and having to fight again...so, once the ACTION finally does start we (the audience) have already been bored to death, then whined at by all the cry-baby Victors...so much so that I WISH I WAS GOING TO BE SLAUGHTERED IN THE ARENA JUST TO END MY BOREDOM OF HAVING TO WATCH THIS MOVIE. They didn't *have* to set the stage for the movie (was already done in the first, and done much better) and re-hash every scene leading up to the arena battle...The entire movie is a bad and short re-hash of every scene from the first movie, and done in a less excitng and less polished way (they figured since you saw the first movie you can fill in the blanks with what you already know, but then why re-do all the same exact scenes in the first place but in a crappier way?). IT makes no sense. Ironically the best scenes you will find in the "deleted scenes" section of the Dvd. And then...THE ENDING...they were building up to a huge climax and then...you saw the credits on the screen...it was over...they wasted too many minutes of run time filming boredom and rehashed scenes of things that already happened in the first movie (combined with the first 40 minutes of nothing) that the 2 hours were up and they couldn't show you the climax. I buy a lot of movies and this one is the worst one i have seen in years and years. Buy and watch the first one and skip this one, not even worth $5., and it costs $20. If they actually make a 3rd one which has the ending of this 2nd movie in it...it *might* be good...but to me that will be the Hunger Games 2 and this will be something to forget exists. They figured that since the first movie was so successful that they could just make another much lower quality carbon copy of the first movie with nothing new...when something new and exciting finally was going to happen, the credits came up and...THE END. They had a good cast and probably a high enough budget to make something good...WHY DIDNT THEY? They don't even show any flattering scenes of Jen...i mean really...Everyone knows she is hot (and so is the other girl with the Axe), why not show off her body in the form-fitting combat suit...just a little, nothing crazy, just show a full body shot of her walking in the suit instead of super zoomed in head shots all the time. The one PG rated scene where the guy hits on her went to the deleted scenes bin...is this movie for 8th grade girls or something and i didn't get the memo?
I love the books.  I love the movies.  I felt this stays close to the storyline of the book.  The movie is exciting, the plot moves along quickly and great acting all around.

I loved Catching Fire! In my opinion it's better than the first one. Finnick and Johanna are my favorite characters in this movie. They're so badass!

Better acting, better story-telling, better effects, and a more enjoyable cast of characters! I wholeheartedly enjoyed this movie and eagerly await the third installment. Unlike the first movie, this one ends with a cliff-hanger, of sorts, and it's just perfect. Can't wait to see the next one!

Having purchased a copy of the first installment, The Hunger Games, I had some expectations for the presentation of the second volume. Some parts from the book that I thought would be important didn't seem to make it to the release cut for this movie, but its hard to present this type of book where the main characters thoughts are important to the plot. The length of the movie seemed deceiving as the action and plot kept moving. The ending leaves it more obvious of a next installment to come. I'll be looking forward to that as well, provided they can retain the same cast.

This movie moved along quickly with some set up, but never a lull.  There are some differences from the book, but it didn't stray too far from the original story line.  It was suspenseful even though I knew what was going to happen from reading the book.  The ending leaves you hanging for the next and final episode.  If you liked the first movie and/or book I'd definitely recommend this one.  It's not just more of the same.  There are twists that make it original and fresh.
As usual the book was much more detailed but this is a good movie to watch. I think they lightened the book for the movie as many of the more violent scenes in the book are not in the movie.

I cant wait for the third Hunger Games movie. Watching this made me want to pick up the books as well.

The Hunger Games trilogy should be read, and deeply thought about, by every American. "Catching Fire" does not disappoint readers of the book or viewers of the first movie. The special effects are extremely well done, and the high standards of acting set in the first movie are maintained in this one. The end of the second book was extremely frustrating to me unless you had the third book in your hands, but this movie has a better ending than the book by adjusting its scope ever so slightly. Very highly recommended.

I wasn't expecting much from this movie, being a huge fan of the book series and a so-so fan of the first movie. But, from the moment I hit /play, I don't remember so much as blinking. I have heard rumors that this movie is based on the Korean drama Battle Royale. Whether that is true or not is not an issue because once I saw the first installment of this series, I was hooked. I was so hooked when I saw the first movie that I purchased the second movie as soon as it was available. I rarely ever do that! I love Katniss and the growth of her character from the first movie. She is more assertive and confident about who she is and more aware of how her actions affect the people around her. Most of the time the length of a movie proves to be detrimental; not so in this case. The time passed by and I hardly even noticed. The first movie left me wondering what would happen to Mr Snow, Katniss and her family and her love(s). I hope that this isn't a spoiler alert, but even if this movie (and most are) is a bit different from the books(which I haven't read yet), The series was so well done that I think that even the diehard bookfans would find it a little bit difficult to criticize too much. I will enjoy seeing the final two installments.

What a pitiful tepid, boring, over-wrought story.  A shadow of the first one.  It drags on to make a bit over 2 hours seem like 5 hours of your life.  The new version of the star is too pitiful to carry on with.  Every significant event isn't a contest between the contestants, it is the result of interference of the game managers.  Which makes the 'combat' a farce in this farce of a tale.

The production values were great, the actors did a bang up attempt, but the direction and writing were beyond pathetic.  I tried to give it two stars, but no, everything else just more than subsumes any good of it all.  A pitiful waste really.  There are perhaps 10 clever minutes in the whole film.  I believe this may have ruined the entire Hunger Games series of movies for me.  I would only watch another if it is free, I am bored, and can find absolutely nothing 'potentially' interesting to do.

I'm a pretty big Hunger Games book fan and I found this film installment to follow the book very well - which is impressive in my mind. It has been a while since I've read the books, so I cannot say for sure where things deviated, but nothing really stuck out to me (unlike other book-to-movies where obvious plots/information is missing/changed). The directorial style of F. Lawrence very closely resembled that of G. Roth in the first movie. Sometimes going between directors in trilogies is so noticeable that it seems like a completely different cast/crew/plot style/etc. This loses the flow between movies and it comes off as a disconnected plot. This was not the case for Catching Fire.

There is not much to say about the cast that has not already been said and noted. They are a great working bunch and it will be interesting to see how the progress into the next film(s), especially with the loss of the talented Mr. Hoffman.
Entertaining movie and enjoyed it with the family. A bit violent for younger ones though. Also thought the ending was weak, like it was obvious it was setting up for the next movie.

great film

I've read all of the books and watched both the first and second movies multiple times, and appreciate both versions of the story. I think the movies capture the major plot points of the books without losing continuity in the storytelling. As with any book to screen adaptation, there are differences and some inconsistencies, but overall they've done a great job. Production quality of this film is up slightly from the first, and I continue to be impressed with the lead actors - some of whom I was a little concerned about when they were first cast, but those concerns have been pleasantly proven unfounded. Katniss' character on screen is less "whiny" than in the books, and I personally feel that she is a stronger character on screen. This can primarily be chalked up to the fact that the books (obviously, since they're told from her perspective) provide a much deeper look at her thinking and emotional struggles than can be directly translated on screen.

In short: Read the books *and* see the movies. They're both pretty awesome.

As far as Amazon streaming quality, I haven't had a problem yet. Great service and easy to purchase and watch. Only major con is that Amazon won't let me watch Amazon movies on my brand-spanking-new tablet. Frustrating, but I have faith that Amazon will evolve and it will happen eventually.

There's a lot of intrigue in the movie plot and lots of action. Katniss is still clueless and uninterested in the swirling discontent among the districts. She just wants to be home and live her life without contest or controntataion. But President Snow had other ideas as do some of the tributes in the sneaky way Snow wants to discredit or better yet eliminate her as a symbol. I loved the way some contestants pulled together in identifying the weak point in the arena and wreaking havoc on it. There I'll stop fo avoid a spoiler. What strikes me is the physical aspect and the strateic element developed along with the key trle of a couple of geeks. You need brains as well as brawn in the arena. I loved the ending and the change in the expression of Katniss' face once aboard the evac. I can't wait for the 2 concluding movies. My summer plan is to read Mocking Jay. Here we go again! "Hunger Games Catching Fire" offers the same cast, same storyline, same results. No surprises plot twists or anything refreshingly new about this film. Donald Sutherland is back with his constant bored expression (much like mine watching this DVD) as President Snow. Elizabeth Bank's acting talent is wasted on the cartoonish ridiculous character Effie Trinket, she resembles an over done Tinker Bell from the Disney films. Then we have Stanley Tucci as TV Host Caesar Flickerman who comes across like a overly tanned TV game show host on steroids.

Jennifer Lawrence gives it her best, but the script here is just so redundant and repetitive that it's a waste of time. These cardboard cartoon like characters go through the acting motions but are lost in a muddled script that can't save this film. The recently released DVD "Divergent" handles this subject matter with a much more mature script material and much more convincing acting. Or try finding the 2001 DVD "Series Seven-The Contenders" a bold realistic film that handles this material with such graphic reality you will actually believe that you are watching a real event not a film. In this film A TV program selects people at random to kill one another for fame and their freedom. Do not fall for the same Hollywood sequel garbage. Look for something new and different.

Love the originality of the story - I always recommend reading the book first, keeps me from getting a predetermined idea of the character's personalities. The book lets you imagine everything to start with. The producers of the movie did a great job sticking with the story and playing out the most important scenes.

This is what a 2nd act should be. In Hunger Games, we were introduced to the world, it's struggles, and the essential characters. It was also an intimate view of the struggles and growth of our main character. In Catching Fire, with introductions out of the way, the series is free to explore the growing unrest and shifting politics of the world beyond 1 person. Unlike in HG, the plot feels much bigger than our main character.

The big downside is you're supposed to feel the stark contrast between HG, where there were just 12-18 year olds fighting, and CF where there are people of all ages. The problem is, in HG, few young people actually looked young and few older people in CF actually looked older. Since most of your main characters in both films look 20-30, any intended contrast is lost.
Really enjoyed The Hunger Games: Catching Fire. I look forward to the next two films. They will hopefully be equally good!

The package came wrapped and the dvd case sealed. I was hoping that the digital copy was through the amazon cloud. It would've been so much easier to activate.
If you don't have an Ultraviolet account one must be created and it's partner account VUDU must be made as well. Why 2 accounts for one digital copy is beyond me. This isn't the first Ultraviolet/VUDU digital movie I have activated and depending on what device VUDU is being watched from it can be lagging or perfect. There was no iTunes option as some digital copies have.
But the digital copy does make it convenient to watch on the laptop while traveling if there's no DVD drive or player available.

Both the books and the movies that tell the story of "The Hunger Games" are amazingly creative, interesting, and riveting.  I recommend reading the books and watching the movies of this trilogy as it involves a serious subject (an oppressive totalitarian government) and how one brave person can make such a huge difference to millions of people.

This epic story is inspiring and focuses on Katniss, who has no interest in being a heroine.  She is a heroine just because of who she is naturally with her sense of honor, her goodness, her outspokenness, her honesty, and her grit.

What is captured in "The Hunger Games," is the battle between the oppressed and the oppressors, something that has plagued Planet Earth for too many centuries.  And what "The Hunger Games" brings to this ongoing plague on Earth is a unique way to present this conflict with hope for the oppressed everywhere.

The stories are more than just "entertainment."  "The Hunger Games" takes a very serious evil and brings it to our consciousness in a real and palatable way.  It causes me to take inspiration from the actions of the heroes and heroines who arise through the very punishment of the games to greatness, which, in turn, incites the oppressed people to rise up and attempt to take back their lives.

"The Hunger Games" merits our attention.

I have only read the first of The Hunger Games trilogy but I have seen-and loved-the movies of the first two volumes of it and can hardly wait for the third (I can't decide whether or not to go ahead and read it or wait). I loved the first in the series but loved Catching Fire even more. It is taut, painful, and exciting, and I gasped and cried my way through it.

It is definitely more meaningful to see this film after seeing the first (or having read the books). It is a tightly written, fast-moving and suspenseful film with many heartbreaking moments. I found the critique of first world power and imperialism excellent but done lightly enough so as not to overwhelm the plot or the characters.

Jennifer Lawrence turns in another outstanding performance. Philip Seymour Hoffman is wonderful and I don't know how they're going to handle his death. All the actors-especially Elizabeth Banks as Effie and Lenny Kravitz (a favorite of mine)-give amazing performances.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. After reading all the books, I had been looking forward to seeing this movie, and was happy with the movie's adaptation of the book. There were a few details/scenes that were left out or are different from the book, but they do not affect the overall story. For example, the movie never shows Katniss going to the old house in the woods near the lake where her and her father used to go, but this doesn't take anything away from the story. Katniss also learns about the uprising in a different manner in the movie (sees it on a television on the train ride to the capital, where in the book she sees it on TV in the Mayor of District 12's house). Look forward to watching it again someday (probably before Mockingjay part 1 comes out).

After watching the Hunger Games movies I checked out some other reviews online and found this quote in a review from Christianity Today:

"Jennifer Lawrence, who plays the lead role of Katniss Everdeen, described Suzanne Collins' Hunger Games trilogy as holding up 'a terrible kind of mirror: This is what our society could be like if we became desensitized to trauma and to each other's pain.'"

The Hunger Games movies, and books which they are based upon, invoke a certain kind of revulsion within toward the indifference and almost awe with which we consume violence as entertainment. I appreciate "entertainment" that is more than just that. This movie certainly gives viewers much to consider.

I have read all 3 books, and have seen the first two movies of this trilogy. This trilogy is all about coming of age, fighting for human dignity and overcoming adversity with cunning and personal skills. Though violent, the movie doesn't dwell on the gory, but on survival, hope and young love.  The author wrote for young adults, but, the message was embraced by young and old alike.  This futuristic story hits very close to home with the injustice of those that Have and Have Not.  Sometimes it only takes the spunk and courage of one person ( Katniss Everdeen) to ignite the masses to defend their rights as human beings. At the conclusion of the 74th Hunger Games, Katniss and Peter manage to survive all that is thrown at them. Unfortunately their retirement to a life of `luxury' is short lived. The Capitol is concerned at the unrest in the districts and at Katniss' popularity in particular. The subsequent 75th Hunger Games is thus designed to put an end to her and re-establish control over the twelve districts. Accordingly, the previous winners of the Games are committed to another round which should see Katniss dead and hope crushed. While this is all conveyed well enough, this installment does not stand alone. You really need to be familiar with the books or at least to have seen the first film in the series.  Even so, things are a little confusing at times. The human dynamics are a bit more complex this time round and much that happens is to set up the next film. I felt this served to let this film down a bit and it all seemed a bit rushed towards the end. Overall the focus is less on the Game itself and more on the rebellion, though it is still pretty good entertainment. There is also some powerful emotional moments at times. It is not too gory and if anything the violence has been toned done a bit. The fact that most of the participants are adults makes it less unsettling than the first installment. Recommended but it needs to be viewed as an episode rather than a self-contained story. Just closer to three stars than four.

I am a big fan of the Hunger Games series of books.  I found them to be excellent stories, very well written with very well thought-out plots.  I was very impressed when the first movie came out, as the main scenes and themes of the book were actually still there.

Catching fire, the 2nd installment in the movie series, is possibly the closest I have ever seen a movie come to the book from which is is drawn.  What's more, those changes that have been made all enhance the on-screen experience.  Once again the plot is fantastic and the acting is superb.  The on-screen action is perfectly balanced with drama and some great moments of humor.

If you enjoyed the hunger games movie, or the books, I highly recommend Catching Fire.  This is a rare instance of a sequel really improving on the original, and I hope that the momentum carries through to the remaining films.

Just like the first movie, Catching Fire follows the book closely. Still angry over Katniss outsmarting him during the last Hunger Games, President Snow with the help of his new game maker, Plutarch, devises a Quarter Quell where the pool will be chosen from the surviving victors in each district. In District 12, that means Katniss is destined to return to the Games, along with either Peeta or Haymitch. When Peeta volunteers as tribute, it sets the scene for Peeta and Katniss to be placed in danger once again, with Haymitch helping them from the Capitol. Unlike last time, where only some of the tributes were skilled fighters, Katniss and Peeta are facing an entire arena of other tributes whose cunning and skill allowed them to survive the Games. Making allies, something Katniss has always struggled with, will be crucial to coming out alive.

Though some of the names and the arena have changed, all the elements that attracted viewers to The Hunger Games movie are present in its sequel. New characters keep things fresh, and it is good to see how the original characters have evolved. Superb acting by all and a gripping story line make this a must see for fans of dystopian fiction. With an outstanding cliffhanger ending, fans will certainly be eager for The Hunger Games: Mockingjay -- Part I to release this fall.

Everyone who's seen this should receive a voucher for free admission to part 3 which hopefully will bring some closure.  Then again, if there's money to be made, parts 4-19 won't be far off.

Wonderful sequel.  This one - to me - follows the book much more closely than the original.  There are some major portions left out, don't get me wrong, but the major points are there.  The graphics in this one are AMAZING!  Let me repeat that - AMAZING.  Terrific graphics throughout the movie.  The only disappointment, really, was that the relationship between Finn and Katniss wasn't as developed as I would have liked to have seen.  Nuts & Volts were perfect casting, in my opinion - although I would have liked to have seen more of them as well.  And Jena Malone as Joanna - for as small a part as she played - was inspired!  Honestly, I liked this one SOOOO much more than the original.  I can't wait to see what they do with Mockingjay.  If you enjoyed the first movie, you will fall in love with this one.  If you didn't like the first movie - there's still a chance you'll like this one - to me it stands on its own.

Well, fortunately, CATCHING FIRE is not like the former or the later.

In this run, Jennifer Lawrence's character is ...Well...on fire! It was just as I imagined. The quarter quell finds Katnis and Pita in a huge dome resembling a tropical forest surrounding an island lagoon. At the center of the lagoon is an island. There is where the weapons are stashed for the brutal contest to come. The capital city has lavishley created a set like no other. All of the former winners of the games are pitched against one another upon this extravagant stage.

Lightning storms! Fogs of acid! Maniacal killer baboons! Tsunami gushing floods! All, Circle the inside of the dome causing mayham and death... seeming random at first. But the clever group that Katnis has drawn together to better their odds for survival, find that the random catastrophes are not so random. And together they begin to form a plan to use the events to their advantage. They desperately need help to fight the stronger and more vicious other group that hunts them relentlessly. For they know Katnis is by far the most popular and leathel among the contenders. She must die if one of them is to leave the dome alive!

CATCHING FIRE is a marked improvement over THE HUNGER GAMES, in everything from the script and story, to the visuals and cinematography. The story continues to follow Katniss (and Peeta) as they do a victory tour of Panem. However, things are not as happy as you think might be. Revolution is brewing, and the people in charge want to nip it in the bud. This is solved by having a special Hunger Games for the 75th year. Instead of fresh tributes, they will be reaped from the existing pool of victors. What follows is a fascinating and engaging look at a dystopian society, the battle for survival, etc. This definitely held my interest better than the limpid previous installment. One thing that's immediately noticeable is the change in visual style, and the way they shot the movie. Instead of a lot of handheld and shaky camera, the shots are better composed, wider and more fluid. This is especially helpful in maintaining a sense of place in the arena. I also liked how they gave more time for character development, even for President Snow. They even manage to give most of the new characters their due onscreen as well. Standouts were Philip Seymour Hoffman as Plutarch Heavensbee and Sam Claflin as Finnick O'Dair(?). The only I really don't care for in these movies is the love triangle between Katniss, Gale and Peeta. Twilight already did it, and every movie since has had some variation on it. Overall, this movie is much better than the first one though, and the final two installments will be directed by the same person (Francis Lawrence). They do a better job with the technical aspects, handling of the story and thematic elements and a much better job of building the world of Panem. Even if you didn't like the first one, you should give this a try.

Middle movies in a trilogy often suffer - first installments usually end with a big reveal, and the finale isn't until the third, so the 2nd movie is left with aftermath from the first and setup for the third. While that's true of Catching Fire as well, it all works, and if anything  Jennifer Lawrence's performance is even better than in the first movie - more pathos and edge as she realizes on an even deeper level the hypocrisy and cruelty of the Capital regime. Although not everyone's performance matches up to hers, they are all fine, and the special effects are excellent.

Plot-wise, Katniss is now home in District 12 after she and Peeta won their Hunger Games. However, their ability to get the Capital to allow them to both live, by acting as if they are deeply in love, has made them a symbol of rebellion, and President Snow warns Katniss she must play the loyalist to keep her loved ones safe. When even this fails to work, a new 75th anniversary Hunger Games is announced, composed of all prior winners, and both Peeta and Katniss are once again in the arena. I don't want to reveal much more as it will spoil the ending, but there's more intrigue than in the first movie, and it's a great setup for the final installment.

I saw the first movie, then read the book. Was a little disappointed, but overall really pleased with the interpretation of mood. For "Catching Fire" I read the book first, then saw the movie and was amazed at how beautifully both the mood and plot points were translated to film. Page to screen adaptations are difficult to do, and this movie makes a valiant and most times successful effort. Fans of the books will delight at the spot-on characterizations, and newcomers will enjoy the action as well as the dark-undertones that remind us only too well of our own world at large.

I haven't read the books and truthfully, never heard of "The Hunger Games" until I rented the first movie on a whim. But I really enjoyed it - and the sequel, "Catching Fire," does not disappoint. The first half of the movie did a good job of humanizing the characters, which in turn made them real and allowed me to sympathize with them throughout the movie. The second half was edge-of-your-seat action with amazing special effects - although the characterization/acting is what stole the show. I was pleasantly surprised to see several veteran actors I enjoy like Jeffrey Wright, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Stanley Tucci and Woody Harrelson, along with newer actors I'm only now familiar with but look forward to seeing more of. It's a long movie but feels fast-paced... I'm wanting more after the sudden ending!!
This is as intense as the hungry games. You will be totally lost if you don't watch the first one first.

Clearly, there is bias for me with the Hunger Games trilogy, as I loved the books, and am not in the least disappointed with the movie adaptation. This was a preorder and was shipped to arrive on the release date, and since the cost was a dollar or two less than what was charged, the difference was credited back to me automatically and quickly. If you love The Hunger Games, this will not disappoint. I can't say enough good things about the film and book trilogy, but if you haven't read the books, then you may feel questions, and that the movie is unfinished or missing something, when you get to the end ...No worries, it's just following along the lines of the book with Catching Fire being the set-up to the continuation in Mockingjay. Essentially, this movie and book are cliffhangers, so enjoy it, and wait as patiently as you can to answer your lingering questions ...or you can read the books, and get an idea on what the next 2 movie installments will be like. Either way, it's not a disappointment and a great action film and storyline to add to your movie collection.
This is where our world is headed if we allow things to continue the way they are. This is very sobering!!!

Oh em jee. I so enjoyed this sequel to the Hunger Games. The rare sequel that was as enjoyable as the first (Spiderman). So rare. Such a great plot twist, I won't spoil it for you. Darn youuuuu, Philip Seymour Hoffman! :( The actors are incredible, you forget it's a movie, you really do.

Well after a discussion at work, a friend told me to check out this new film just released on blu ray, says it's a great film, great effects and plenty of bonus extra's. Being a massive Lord of the Rings fan I'd been waiting along time for these new prequels to come out. So it arrived and I sat down to watch the first in this new series of three 'catching fire'. Well after an hour into it (yes I was enjoying it) I kind of got the impression I was missing something here, like a build up and introduction of the characters, tell me a bit out them and how they came to take part in these games. Because of this I found it hard to relate to the characters and I didn't really know why these relationships had taken place. It was like boom, straight in with the story. After this first film I can't really see where it is going or how it will link into future films. As for the title, hunger games, you thought it would be focusing the story on food but it isn't actually and is quite misleading, I also failed to see anybody catching on fire as well. But that's a minor gripe. The main highlight for me was the return to the big screen of Woody Allen, he hasn't featured in many big films for a long time and I thought his demeanor suited his character haymish very well so that's a plus for the film.
