It wasn't a bad movie. It would just be really confusing if you haven't read the books. The relationship that builds between Peeta and Katniss in the book is just not there. There is maybe two actual moments shown in the movie. One conversation and one time he helps her sleep after a nightmare. In the book, the relationship builds in a totally believable way that will be relevant later. So not sure how they are going to pass that off in the next movie. Build up to certain events were side swept in ways that are going to make the third movie confusing. They cut out the significance of the Mockingjay symbol which is so important. It is so slightly mentioned and easy to overlook. In fact it turns into "We will all wear gold".. The next movie/book is CALLED Mockingjay for Pete's sake. They never mention that she hears rumor of District 13 existing. President Snow smelling like blood and roses is cleverly shown with blood flooding into is champagne glass but if you don't know what your seeing it could easily be missed. There are just so many major things left out that it ends up feeling vague and boring. I know there was a lot of information to cram into an already long movie but even if they just showed clips of Peeta and Katniss falling asleep together, or having a moment of doing something other than staring into a crowd being sad. Show him comforting her when no one else could. Show the gamemaker showing off his Mockingjay watch, just little snip its to help the story along. Made me sad that such simple changes could have brought so much more life to this story.  People who are upset with the ending, it wasn't terribly well done but it ends as the book does and will pick right back up. I would be scared for the third installment except that it was so poorly written that a movie version has to be better.

Its been awhile since I read The Hunger Games trilogy, but I think that my dislike for the finale clouded my opinions of Suzanne Collins popular series. Catching Fire the movie, did an excellent job of reminding me why I like the series and making me fall in love with it all over again.

The story is simple; Katniss and Peetas bold plot at the end if the 74th Hunger Games made them the capitols sweetheart and the symbol of rebellion in the districts. The President wants to kill Katniss, the districts want her to lead them and Katniss just wants to live her life. Oh, wait did I say simple? Nope, just because these stories are written for the YA crowd doesnt mean they are simple. A friend of mine who saw the film with me, but hasn't read the books said it perfectly that is one of the most intense films I have seen in awhile. Intense is right.

It starts and everything seems fine. Katniss is still out there hunting with Gale and her family is safe, but it is not fine. Katniss lives in Victors village with Peeta and Haymitch. This issue is that Peeta is still angry to discover that her love in the games was just an act and just because both his mentees survived hasn't erased the memories or alcohol from Haymitchs system. And to make matters worse, its beginning again. The 75th Hunger Games are looming closer and Katniss and Peeta must put on their smiles, hold hands and pretend that all is well. If they don't the evil and way too involved President Snow will make them pay.

As Katniss, Jennifer Lawrence is perfect. There is some touch and go in the beginning as she has no real chemistry with Liam Hemsworths Gale, but once Katniss  blooms and decides to fight, the magic happens. She becomes the girl I fell in love with on the page. Part fierceness, part vulnerability and all around stubborn. The character is brilliant. A true hero in a world of Bella Swans, a girl with a bow and arrow.  Katniss Everdeen the girl on fire is one of my favorite statements in the literary world.  And Jennifer Lawrence makes that statement. She gives the kind of performance that makes you forget her public persona, forget the Oscar and the blond hair and simply see Katniss.

I have always been a fan of Peeta Mellark. I shipped him with Katniss and Josh Hutcherson reminds me of that love in every scene he appears in. Peeta may be stronger than he looks, but he is no warrior. He hasn't struggled to survive like Katniss and Gale did for all those years. He had a comfortable life, considering. He was the Bakers son and the differences between Katniss and Peeta makes them perfect compliments for each other. Peeta is great with people, with manipulating a crowd and making people love him. Hes aware that hes going to die in the games and just like in the 74th games every move he makes is to ensure Katniss survival. Which, in my humble opinion, makes him the best possible romance hero of teen fiction in awhile.

Whats great about Catching Fire, is that you see his change. Hes still Peeta, but hes smarter, craftier and yes we even see the boy with the bread kill. And thats the heartbreaking thing about the games. They aren't just the symbol that keeps the districts in line. They are also the killer of innocence. The reaping and the games changes everyone it touches. It takes children and makes them survivors and killers and then calls them victors. No one wins the hunger games, not even Prim who Katniss volunteered to save. In Catching Fire, Prim is older, less innocent and stronger. She takes duties her mom cant handle and completes them without a flinch. Another causality, another child Katniss couldn't save.

Talking about save, surviving and victors, Catching Fire understands the essence and heart of the series and brings it to life. I found myself wiping tears from my eyes through out the film at the injustice, at the sadness and at the heart of these characters. There is an amazing scene where the victory tour lands in District 11 that had me in tears. Our victors walk on to the stage and there in living color is an image of youthful, beautiful and innocent Rue. It gets to Katniss. It gets to Peeta and it gets to us.

Emotions aside, Catching Fire is an amazing work of cinema. I don't think Suzanne Collins is a Pulitzer writer, but her story is definitely cinematic. The world she created is as theatrical as it is real. The director does an amazing job of always making us aware of the space we reside in while being intimate with the characters. Panems Capitol is different from District 12 and 12 is different from District 11. The Hunger Games series is an art directors dream with its ability to be visually scrumptious in one scene and heartbreakingly drab in the next. Its powerful, the visuals in the film and its intelligently utilized by the filmmakers to give us everything possible to make the world we read about as real as possible.

OH! And to anyone who is wonderingSam Caflin and Jena Malone are AMAZING as Finnick and Johanna. Like electrifying. Caflins Finnick jumped off the screen at me ten times more powerfully than the character in the book. Watching this cocky, pretty and self-centered victor carry Mags on his back is just breathtaking and reveals so many amazing details about his character.  I worried about how the filmmakers would portray Johanna, she can come off like a bitch, but Jena Malone got it. Johanna is angry. She is pissed off and a little crazy and the filmmakers go it right.

I really enjoyed this film. It is filled with intense action, thrills and emotional scenes that reveal the humanity in each of the characters. Theres a bit of touch and go in the beginning, due to the awkward intro scenes with Gale and dialogue that serves simply as exposition. Still, fans of the series will love this film and I think that the people who still haven't read it will run to their nearest bookstore and get it in hand. This is a series about so much more than love triangles or kids killing each other for sport. Armed with an incredible cast of supporting actors and more importantly, incredible characters, Katniss Everdeen incites a revolution.

Catching Fire the movie was so much better than Catching Fire the novel (and I have never in my life said anything like that before!  The movie is almost always never better than the novel).  Thats not to say that the novel wasn't good, however some of the problems with the novel version weren't introduced in the theatrical version; in the novel Katniss became such a cry baby  someone who kills to survive and is the leader of her household should not have been so easily blindsided when it came to the Capital.  Also, banging your head crying over unrequited love (maybe unrequired love because she still doesnt know which love she wants) is eye-rolling over dramatic.

All that aside, since the filmmakers didn't introduce those blaring character discrepancies into the movie, I really enjoyed Catching Fire.  Jennifer Lawrence has proved again that she is perfect as Katniss  so much so, that I prefer her portrayal of Katniss better than Suzanne Collins rendition of Katniss.  The other actors (Josh Hutcherson as Peeta, Liam Hemsworth as Gale and Jenna Malone as Johanna) are absolutely solid.  Jenna Malones portrayal of Johanna actually made me empathize with her character (empathy was not something Johanna eluded in the novel).  The scenes where the citizens of the Districts risked life and limb to give Katniss the show of solidarity was emotionally stirring  because you could feel the oppressive nature of the Capitals governing.

I highly recommend this movie (I also recommend the book.  It is still a really good read).  I am so glad that with the Hunger Games franchise we are presented with a heroine who is strong (but not superwoman), smart and kind.  I will say that the who will she pick scenario is tired and makes Katniss selfish (since shes placing two other peoples feelings on hold while she decides which one she wants).

This is one of those sequels that simply extracts the necessary details, edits the material in an interesting way, and shows off its own spectacle. But, it does it in a great way that most sequels fail to do.
As for the DVD/Bluray combo pack, this is a great deal. You get an HD image that is beautifully shot (which includes the awesome IMAX scenes in the arena), and over two hours of bonus material that blew my mind away.
As for the film itself, I have included my facebook review from when the film released in theaters.

Just got to see The Hunger Games: Catching Fire! The excitement that's been building up for this movie has finally calmed down. Is that a bad thing? Here's how it goes: I would give the film a rating of 10, but there are three things about it that depressed my optimistic view of the film. I'll try not to spoil anything.

1. It felt a bit rushed, and they left out some key elements that are spilled out in the book. I kind of expected this, so I wasn't too upset. But they did follow the book very well.
2. It didn't have the same amount of vigorous thrill that the first film embodied, and instead of expanding that superb energy and making it bigger, they took away a pound of that flame and left it a tad flat. This is probably the biggest downfall of Catching Fire, most likely caused by the switched director and short time frame for filming, making it feel like a Hollywood style action adventure epic rather than the ultimate movie you we're hoping for.
3. The ending is quite a cliffhanger, and feels like it was thrown in at the last moment(probably true), giving you this feeling of "Great, another sequel.", rather than "What's gonna happen next?!" I was almost going to say that the movie was terrible because of the way they left me at the end. But then realized it was intentional.
I realized that this last scene probably was shot during the filming of Mockingjay Part 1, which started filming just two months before Catching Fire came out.

Because of this, I have a bit more mercy for the movie, and decided that Catching Fire deserved a good 9 out of 10. Yes, my expectations we're too high, but the good news is they are spending more time working on the climax, which hopefully comes off as a more focused installment to make up for the few downfalls in it's sequel. Improvements: The Visuals are stunning, and pay a punch to the fake-looking mutts in the first film. the emotion and integrity still hold strong, which is Catching Fire's greatest asset besides Jennifer Lawrence. And finally, even though it hangs you on your toes, it gets you ready for the next chapter, Mockingjay, opening next November.
My advice: don't read the book first, and instead enjoy the movie like it was intended to be.

I'm not a big fan of many sequels, although sequels these days seem to be generally much better than they used to be.  In the case of The Hunger Games: Catching Fire, I can't honestly say that I enjoyed it as much as the original, but I neither can I say that it is "bad" or merely "okay".  It is still a very well-done film and Jennifer Lawrence does such a great job of inhabiting her character that she's a joy to watch.  The appearance of Philip Seymour Hoffman is also a plus.  With the upcoming sequel (the final sequel?), however, it will be interesting to see who they come up with to fill his role.  Again, I'm not going to wade into attempting to go over all the plot-points, etc of Catching Fire.  Suffice it to say that if you enjoyed the original, you'll probably enjoy this sequel as well.  It's very well done and there's some all around good acting, costuming & set designs that are just about guaranteed to keep you entertained.

I can definitely recommend this one.

Sharp as a flaming arrow and as explosive as when one hits a forcefield, "The Hunger Games: Catching Fire" is the rousing, thought-provoking action epic the first movie failed to be. Director Francis Lawrence has done the book justice as he provides the pacing and the gravity the series needs as novelist Suzanne Collins' series grows into an epic drama set in a world on the brink of revolution. Though the move is not perfect due to the number of 'conveniences' the movie uses to add themes to the plot, Catching Fire definitely caught my eye and mind while watching the blockbuster.

The movie presents a kind of conundrum for me. Theres no doubt that I mostly liked it a lot more than the first one. Its better written and certainly far better directed. Despite a central problem that was expressed by one of the characters in the course of the film, and a general tendency toward pomposity, the first two-thirds of Catching Fire is truly compelling. Unfortunately, that last third is something else altogether. Once the movie gets to the actual games, it feels like its on auto-pilot. Its like sitting through that second Quidditch match in the Harry Potter films, which is to say, its kind of a drag. Even a brace of CGI effects don't really liven it up. I will concede that the twist at the very end promises a more intriguing sequel, but its not enough to undo the tedium of the game  at least for me.

The first sections of Catching Fire are very well done in building the sense of oppression. Most of the characters are better drawn this time (of course, they still have all those dopey names) and a lot of the dialogue is surprisingly sharp. Some of the scenes are quite striking. (Thank you, whoever ditched shaky-cam Gary Ross for the more professionally inclined director, Francis Lawrence.) The growing unsettled nature of the populace as Katniss and Peeta undertake their victory tour is beautifully structured. The sequence in the capitol where Katniss dances with game designer Plutarch Heavensbee is not only nicely staged, but their dialogue and its delivery is spot-on with many hidden messages.

However, its also in this part of the film that theres an exchange between Katniss and her mentor, Haymitch, in which he tells her that she could never be worthy of Peetas love for her. Right then, something that had been niggling at me through both films came into focus  hes right. Theres just not much to the Katniss character. Im sure Ive just committed some kind of heresy with that statement, but really, without Jennifer Lawrence in the role, Katniss would be pretty unbearable. Even with her, shes still incredibly oblivious to just about everything. Shes largely self-centered  at least self-absorbed  and always greets the fallout from anything she does with utter astonishment. She remains blissfully unaware of whats going on around her. She didn't realize that her mockingjay-gown transformation would play badly for the safety of its creator, Cinna? Seriously?

Overall, though, the film has much to recommend it. The character portrayals are often brilliant. Harrelson and Elizabeth Banks are far better  and deeper  here than they were in the first film. Philip Seymour Hoffman is brilliant in a tricky role. Stanley Tucci  with that ghastly orange tan and blazingly white teeth, like one of those vapid E! Entertainment News creatures  is the perfect incarnation of the smug TV host with smarmy familiarity and endless fake gushing. Not only that, but he manages to suggest an undercurrent of fear of falling out-of-favor with the ever-fickle powers that be. This is the sort of thing that raises the film a notch more than its rather facile depths. Too bad that the most of the last act is so much a retread of the first movie. Hopefully, the sequels will get around that.

Oh, this movie was great! No complaints whatsoever.

To be honest, whether it be the first installment, this one, or the next, I will always have doubts regarding how true-to-the-book and how well the directors will be able to bring this original book series to life, but I was blown away by Catching Fire! The Capital, the districts, the reaping were somewhat how I imagined it, and a WHOLE lot better. I would even say that it surpasses the first film by far. The games were more thrilling and had me on the edge of my seat!

The movie starts off with an eerie background music, and a scene of Katniss spending time in her district before the victory tour--that usually takes place after the games, and you really get to see how badly the victors are scarred from its experience. Jennifer Lawrence was amazing ... Not much to say  about Josh Hutcherson and his character, Peeta Mellark, but how as equally fantastic they are. The actors, in fact, were all enticing, they really brought life to the characters they portrayed.

The training scene was surreal! I litterally had to stop the movie and rewatch it again and again. Like I said, way better than the first film.

The plot. Before Catching Fire was out in theaters, there were rumors that it will be split into two parts, I was not happy with that, which is why I am glad the directors and screenwriters decided to make it all in one film. With such a complex story, you would think how impossible it is to cram the events and details all together in a two hour or so project, but it worked! There are people who complain about "this detail was not in there!" or "why did they not add this or that scene?!" Well as I see it, the film has most of the important details and you have to keep in mind that not every single detail will be able to fit into the time frame, directors have to make the story make sense, as well as satisfying the different types of viewers, get over it.

Can I watch Catching Fire without watching The Hunger Games and still understand the story? Sure, why not? In this film, there are flashbacks of the previous installment, so even if you did not read the books or watch The Hunger Games, you will still be able to enjoy it. My family did! Though, by watching the the first film, you will be able to better relate with the characters, which makes the events much more emotional and thrilling.

Not much more to say. Simply, I Loved it and it was one of the best movies I have watched, in the YA genre, for a while. Cannot wait, for third installment, Mocking Jay! The ending of Catching Fire really has fans amped up!

Katniss finds that she is a symbol of a budding revolution and must survive another game rigged with deadly surprises.  Will she triumph and does she want to be more than a symbol to the rebels, but a leader?  Exciting, but obviously a lead-in to the next "Games".

I have to admit, I was VERY late to the Hunger Games party.  When the world went crazy for the franchise in written form, I completely tuned it all out.  I was, in my mind, above all that.  This was for teens, right?  Im sorry, but I don't read those Twilight books nor do I see those movies and I was not about to waste my time with some teen oriented book on kids killing kids (seriously, why is this a thing?) and so despite all my friends kids raving the books, I looked at them like they were crazy and went on my merry way.  When the film was made, I was also pretty much a staunch objector.  I was looked at as a villain in the fantasy lives of my friends teenage kids who all wore their hair in braids and started pinning every picture they could find of current it girl, Jennifer Lawrence.  I was kind of adverse to anything Lawrence related at that time.  I had seen a handful of her films, including her Oscar nominated turn in 2010s Winters Bone and I just found her incredibly wooden and uninteresting.

Then I was on a plane to Europe and my friend leans over to me and says have you read The Hunger Games yet? and I looked at him in shock, like WHY ON EARTH DID YOU READ THAT? and he proceeds to tell me that he read all three books over the course of a single weekend (he was apparently sick with the flu) because his daughter was reading them and he thought they were great.

It just did not compute, like at all.

When I got home he wound up lending me the first book and I, begrudgingly, started to read it.  I read it in a weekend and I instantly wanted more.  No, its not a great book.  The writing is actually pretty terrible in parts, and the concept is kind of ridiculous (and seriously, this is for kids?) but the way that the story is told is pretty engaging and I had to admit to myself; I kind of understood the draw.

So I saw the movie.

I have since become a fan of Jennifer Lawrence.  I know some people don't see what I see in her, and I completely understand the aversion to her.  Shes crude and rude and she babbles and says things that could be perceived as offensive and she seems incredibly attention hungry despite trying to play it all off like shes above it, but shes hilarious and in a sea of celebrities who SAY.EXACTLY.WHAT.THEY.THINK.WE.WANT.TO.HEAR. I love that she just says whatever comes to her mind.  She also proved me completely wrong about her talent when she blew me away in The Silver Linings Playbook, so I was not only a fan of her persona, but kind of fell in love with the complete package.  No, shes not my favorite actress out there (and I do find her fans kind of ridiculous) but I like her now.

Oh, shes good as Katniss, since that applies to this particular conversation.

Ok, so after seeing The Hunger Games I was intrigued to where the rest of this story was going to go.  I snatched up the second book, Catching Fire and prepared myself for the movie.  I kind of hated the book.  It felt like a real slump with drawn out segments that didn't further the story and a lazily conceptualized finale that felt like a rehash of the previous games and left me soured.  It wasn't terrible, and it thankfully didn't have those stupid mutant dogs, but I was severely letdown.  I knew that Id see the movie and I knew that Id read Mockingjay (I haven't yet, but I will before the movie is released later this year), but that was more because I hate leaving anything unfinished and so I had to complete the trilogy, but I cant say that I was as excited to see Catching Fire as I had been to see The Hunger Games.

I finally watched this last night, after feeling uncompelled to go to the theater to see it despite being invited by the same friend who lent me the books to begin with.

This is one of those rare instances where the film is actually better than the book, and where the sequel is actually better than the original.  Still, this is far from perfect, but where the book felt tedious, redundant and apathetic, the film found ways to make each point feel necessary.  It omitted moments that didn't matter and nipped things in the bud, which was quite shocking considering that the movie is almost two and a half hours long.  It all felt so brisk.  Before I knew it, the movie was over and it seriously felt like I had only been in front of the television for like an hour, tops.

From a technical standpoint, this film is also a pretty big upgrade.  The visuals are much better this go around, and some of the cinematography is beautiful (but the lighting during the night scenes is awful).  The acting is a mixed bag (Sutherland is just perfection, but Clafin is shockingly ineffective, and while I wanted to love Malone I found her delivery kind of forced) but the returning cast mostly ups their game, especially Banks, who finds layers beneath the makeup.  Harrelson is awful here, completely phoning in each line, but thankfully his awful hair distracted me from his talking.

Yes, the cliffhanger basically forces you into actually seeing the final film(s), but this is the kind of film that makes you want to do just that.  In fact, Im almost tempted to skip the book and just see the movie; but Im pretty sure I won't do that.

Your very first experience with this film is with the dialogue which should leave you wondering what level audience this film is trying to reach. I would guess it to be any barely functioning ninth grader as their maximum literacy marketing level. Acting was robotic with actors chosen for eye candy appeal. Plot wise, The Hunger Games is "starving" from a lack of creative storytelling; just farfetched improbabilities filling 3/4ths of film. Really now, bow & arrows (arrows magically replenish themselves) in this super high tech futuristic environment. Finally, it closes with the same old ending we've seen before, i.e. brief, boring scenes of someone quickly (for budgetary reasons) dying. Even then you really don't see much of that person's finale - they just cheaply disappear. The lack of an ending/closure is transparent storytelling for profit.
Watch "The Starving Games" spoof/parody of this movie for it's spot-on exposure of the juvenile mass marketing appeal of this movie.

They stuck fairly close to the book when they adapted Catching Fire to film, even more so than with The Hunger Games. The overall tone of CF is more serious, Haymitch is more well, Haymitch. For those who haven't read the books (you really should), there's action, stirrings of uprising in the districts, and a side of romance. There is a lot of development in the plot and characters in Catching Fire. The movie may seem a little lengthy around halfway or so, and you may question where all of the action is from the first installment - where the story is leading; rest assured it is all there and there is a point to the beginning. There is a bit more action in the book, such is the case when packing a 12 hour story into a couple of hours screen time.

then you'll have to watch this movie!  If you didn't WATCH Hunger Games, I would say definitely go back,

It's a bit darker than Hunger Games (yeah, really!--maybe you thought that was dark enough?) although
actually there is probably less blood shed in this one.  Still as the plot thickens, it grows increasingly
serious.  I haven't read the books, and usually people who read the book first always complain the movie
left too much out.  Generally I feel a novel and a film have to be thought of as separate works of art and
not directly compared.  In this case, I think several pieces of plot or just...items were introduced that the
movie itself didn't explain adequately, though this was not enough to spoil my appreciation for the film
as a whole.  I had hoped the "bonus features" on Blu-Ray would go into more detail about the background
that the movie didn't have time to fill in, but no...not unless it's in the "commentary soundtrack" if you have
another 3 hours to listen to THAT.  Regardless, the characters, the plot, the visuals, everything in Catching
Fire fully lived up to the quality in the first film.  Turns out there are 2 more movies to go; like the Harry Potter
series, it will take 2 films to deal with the conclusion.  I intend to watch both.
Would recommend reviewing the first movie.  Somewhat confusing in the beginning.  I will watch again to see things that I might have missed the first time.

I thought this movie was exciting and full of great symbolism.  I loved all of the characters but I was a little confused by the weird people of the city at first.  The main character was believable and the plot was complex enough to hold my interest.  I want to see the first one now.

'Catching Fire' stayed very true to the book. The acting was exceptional, as always, and the story line was very interesting. My girlfriend and I were on the edge of our seats. The cinematography was beautiful.
It lagged, a lot of holes in plot. It was good but the first movie was great. I will watch when the next movie comes out

First Movie is still better,  but this is more of the same reloaded.  I know its a Triology, and its good.  The Movie is Alegory for a Communist Revolution...sad...  This is propaganda,  and people are devouring it.  I enjoy a movie for a movie's sake, but I am keenly aware of the intended underlying message.  Sad too, taints great actors and a great movie.

I was not expecting such a well-rounded movie. I had read the book and usually the book is different from the movie, but this was surprizingly similar.  I like it when a movie follows the book withour emblelishments or misdirection or ommissions.
you will enjoy the movie like you never enjoyed a movie before. it keeps you off your seat the entire time. Totally recommend it .

Having read the book, Catching Fire, I can say that this is a very faithful adaptation.

The production value is much higher in the second installment, and you can really tell from the scenes in the arena.  The main actors (Jennifer Lawrence, Josh Hutcherson) seem much more comfortable in their roles. I still think Donald Sutherland is terrible in this role. He just has the same blank look on his face no matter what he's saying or what's being said to him. Frustrating!  The new characters are pretty interesting and they do a good job setting up the twist at the end.  Philip Seymour Hoffman is completely forgettable, as he suffers from the same problem as Donald Sutherland---blank expression, no emotion in the way he speaks.

Most of all, this movie has me excited for the next installment, even though I think it is stupid to split it into 2 movies.
Superb sequel to an amazing first movie. The cliffhanger was well done. I have never read the books but I enjoy these movies.

I liked it, but my husband didn't. I'd have to agree with him on it being a bit tedious at first. (victory tours)  Being a fan of  Face Off, I found myself looking at each character, their make up and what the wardrobes. Great job! The transition of the bridle gown into the Mocking Bird was awesome! I did notice that the only time Katniss had an "accent" when was she called out for Peter, which was a bit off putting. All in all, was it a great movie? No, but Am looking forward to the next release as it did leave me wanting to see more. Perhaps the next sequel will have a bit more "meat" for the audiences to chew on.

I loved this movie!  I loved the book and the movie followed the book pretty closely (they don't always).  The cast fit their parts, the scenery was good.  The only thing I didn't like was the fact that it ended and we have to wait for the next part to come out.  I would recommend this to anyone over the  age of 13.
The Hunger Games: Catching Fire was even better than the second book in my opinion!  Jennifer Lawrence delivered a wonderful performance.
Loved it!! Watched it twice lol! This was such an intense movie and cant wait to see the next. Thanks!
This movie sucks like the first one, same plot spend two thirds of the trying to make you believe this is love story, rebelian

This movie, like its predecessor, tries hard to preserve the feel and as much of the plot as possible from the book.  It does a pretty good job.  The acting and special effects are good and there is a lot of intensity throughout.  The main beefs I have with it have to do with the plot and they are just as they are in the book, so what are you going to do?  I was happy to purchase this film and I'm sure I will watch it a few times.  Any weaknesses you find with it are pretty much taken from the book.
This one is Less violent I think.  Can't wait for the third and final installment.  The third Book was amazing.....

I've read all the books, and in my view, the book was better than the movie. I think there was only so much they could fit into 2+ hours, but I wanted more time in the arena, more Finnick, more about the other tributes. The books goes so much more into them. It took an hour to even get in to the arena. The ending was an abrupt cliffhanger. Since I've read the books, it's not a big deal for me. I really liked Peeta in this one. He came across as such a decent and genuine person. I am totally Team Peeta now. He is so selfless. Katniss is too, but Peeta has much more of an emotional core and likeability. The acting is superb. Jenna Malone stole every scene she was in, but I wanted more of her. I love all the characters and there were some great action scenes (loved the crazed orangutans). I bought the DVD because I knew I'd watch it in the years to come. I knew I'd like it, but there was just something slightly missing for me, therefore, the four stars rather than five. Overall, a great movie. If you haven't read the books, you will probably enjoy this one more than the first Hunger Games movie.

If you haven't seen this movie yet and you have read the book, this series for whatever reason is closely following the books, and it's well worth seeing.  The entire cast pulls it off amazingly well.  Jennifer Lawrence should won an Oscar for this, and instead was nominated for a silly remake of the 70s (American Hustle).  I watched it yesterday and it was a so-so movie one would expect of a highly nominated yet not very well accepted by the consumer.
I feel Jennifer Lawrence captured the depth and breadth of the novel in this movie. The action was intense - the acting superb. It made the novel come alive. I look forward to the next adventure!

 When it was over, I thought it was really very well done and thoroughly enjoyable. A very acceptable continuation of the story.

After renting the movie the streaming begins with a spinning circle in the middle of the screen while streaming, then 2 or 3 minutes of viewing, then more streaming for a few minutes. when you rent a movie from amazon you would at least expect to be able to down load it really

I can watch Hunger Games over and over and it seems to smoothly go from one scene to the next. While Catching Fire continues this streak for the first half it seems to stumble in the second. Right around the time Cinna (Lenny Kravitz) gets beat, the series starts to feel beat (and I braved crowds of 12 year olds to see this on opening night). The arena redux just isn't that exciting, especially since hardly any of the contestants even want to kill each other by that point. Then there are weak elements such as scary fog, killer monkeys, and (worst of all) "tick tock".  And ok, ok... we get it that the girl is the stronger District 12 contestant, but how many times did Peeta need to be carried? And Katniss' shooting the sky was even more lame than he was. I really hope Mockingjay Parts 1 and 2 are cohesive the way the first movie was.
great follow up!  loved it!  waiting now for part three to come out!  actors were  fantastic!  just thank you very much

Jennifer Lawrence shines once again in the second installment of "The Hunger Games" and her supporting cast was just as good.  We see Katniss and Peta grow closer to what will inevitably bring them together as they did in the books but you also see heartbreak when the two are separated.  You start to see that the love that lied about in the first movie to save them begins to manifest into something real for the guy (Peta) that everyone wants her to end up with.  It was also amazing performances from Woody Harrelson and of course an incredible performance by the late/great Phillip Seymour Hoffman.  If you are a fan of the books and you loved the first movie and love Jennifer Lawrence then this is right up your alley.  Don't do yourself any injustice...WATCH THIS MOVIE!

The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013). Rated "PG-13". Running Time: 2 hours, 32 mins. This is the second movie, the sequel to The Hunger Games [HD] (2012). Returning: Jennifer Lawrence, Liam Hemsworth, Woody Harrelson, Donald Sutherland, Willow Shields, Elizabeth Banks, Josh Hutcherson, Stanley Tucci, Lenny Kravitz, Jack Quaid, Sandra Ellis Lafferty, Paula Malcomson, Bruce Bundy, Nelson Ascencio, Mehmet Korhan, Eli Shannon, Bailee Watters, Amandla Stenberg, Dayo Okeniyi. Katniss (Jennifer Lawrence) is in the woods in deep thought. Gale (Liam Hemsworth) finds her. She has 2 hours before she leaves for the end of her tour. While she is hunting for turkeys, she sees a vision of someone and it scares her. Gale tells her no one is there and to relax. She walks Gale home and while talking, she tells him about the games and she did what she had to do to survive. Gale kisses her once. She goes to Haymitch's (Woody Harrelson) home and he is in a drunken sleep. She wakes him up and tells him the cameras will be here in an hour. When she goes home to her family, they have a visitor. The guards take her to President Snow (Donald Sutherland). He invites Katniss to play a real game. he says he doesn't want to kill her. Effie (Elizabeth Banks) and Cinna (Lenny Kravitz) come to meet Katniss. Katniss and Peeta go outside and act in front of the cameras for Caesar's (Stanley Tucci) national show. Katniss and Peeta kiss to play like the sweethearts the Capitol wants. Then it is back on the the high speed train to the Capitol. President Snow and Plutarch (Philip Seymour Hoffman) have a plan to get Katniss in the 75th Hunger Games. The plan is to kill her. Also in the cast: Jeffrey Wright, Amanda Plummer, Jena Malone, James Logan. Philip Seymour Hoffman died February 2, 2014. He had already filmed scenes for the sequels to be released in 2014 and 2015. The Hunger Games [HD] (2012). The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013). The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1 (2014). The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2 (2015).
Good movie even my 2 1/2 yr old enjoyed the movie.  It kept his attention and he loved it!! Great family movie!!!

I have read all the books, and the movie is not better than the book. For a movie,  however, it was enjoyable to watch.  I think a person who has not read the book will like it better. I spent a lot of time trying to make sense of the movie in regards to the book.

I would recommend this movie to all. It has everything you'd hope from the first installment of "The Hunger Games". It"s Better Than the first actually so i pop up seat and put this movie on and enjoy.
Lots of action, really good stunts,  great special effects. Over all the storyline leaves you angry at the bad guys.
Because, the movie is very eye catching. It is a very good movie, very intriguing. I absolutely loved both of them.
Its a Good movie.  Just not "edge of your seat good". I would recommend watching; looking forward to the next one!
Very good movie!! The special effects were awesome and the acting was superb. It's not often you see sequel that's as good as the first movie.
Love the book and love the movie even more! A must see for all and definitely one I will purchase!!
It was ok not great it seemed to drag at times. Not bad just not great! 3rd will be better
Tried to watch it twice , it just didn't hold my attention.  Seemed predictable and repetitive.  It was not money well spent.
I like to keep things short and sweet, I can't wait for part 3. I will purchase the Blu-ray. Just awesome.
The movie stayed right along with the books. My hubby hates to read, so it was nice for him to get the real story. Unlike the first one. " no explaining the real story:)"
Great movie! Liked Hunger Games a bit better, though.  You will not be disappointed with this movie.  Jennifer Lawrence's acting is stellar, as always.
Awesome movie. I just felt bad for those who did not read the book first because it would have helped to understand certain elements of the story.
It was amazing in 3D in theaters, and it is just as good in 2D at home on my 34 inch television. My father watched the Blu-Ray on his big screen and said it was amazing. All around, good deal
Great movie very good sequel to the girst cant wait for the third to come out got us eager too
Catching Fire is an awesome movie and now I cant wait for the next one. Talk about a cliff hanger.

I usuallly reserve 5 stars for only my top 2% all favorite films, so that is why I am giving this four stars.  But it was a very good movie, and it tied into the first movie well.  The story is pretty original, being derived from the books on which it was based (which I never read), and it is one of the few films that I have seen do a very good job of crossing filming styles between traditional-filmmaking and reality-style filmmaking.  This film does a wonderful job of adding just enough of the new style to bring it some edge, but not so much that it obscures the storyline.  From what I have seen from both the frist and second films, the main characters are moved by love despite everything that they are made to endure, and in my opinion, that is really makes the characters shine!
Story line was good and the action was good but the way it ended left a sour taste. Why not finish the game!
Even my mother likes this movie.  I do think that you need to read the books if you want to fully understand this movie.
The first one was great...this one lacked and the ending was very disappointing. I hope the next one is more like the first.
Continues the story from part 1in a semi-predictable way. Knowing there will be three parts made it a necessary viewing.
They are following along with the series and are really doing wonderfully. Great story and wonderful characters. Magnificent scenery and wardrobe.

Great movie that follows the book pretty well in comparison to other "book to movie" films. The characters are developed well and the movie is entertaining at least if you haven't seen the first movie or read the books.
Love this series.  Really follows the book.  Jennifer Lawrence plays Katniss so well.  The effects were good too.  Definitely worth your time.
just receive my copy and i'm really sad that the description didn't said all the audio tracks and i needed it to have french audio options on it and didn't have it when i opened it !

Of course must watch the first of this series to appreciate this one and this a decent enough follow-on to the first. Plot twists, character interacts, special effects....... In the end an action movie with revolution undertones. Date movie? Yes. Viewing with spouse? Yes. Children? Not under the age of 15, 16. Guys only? Sure. And if you like this movie, you will want to watch the coming third installment of the "story".
Great pacing and effects. Sure it can't live up to the book but really a truly enjoyable movie. See it!
They seem bent on following formulas and setting up melodramatic non-surprises?  The Actors did very well.  But there seems a lack of empathy in the casting.
Loved the book , love the movie , my husband even thought it was a really good movie .  Can't wait for the next one
I've read all these books, and Hollywood does a good job of creating the characters and keeping with the original theme of the books. The books can't be beaten though. I'm so glad I read them 1st.
This was a very interesting movie, never a dull moment. I watched it twice. In a movie this fast paced, things are missed first time.
Generally well done; a few incontinuities, such as the quiver  seems bottomless; in one scene 3 arrows left, next scene quiver is full.  Doesn't detract from the movie though
The acting was good the story not too bad but was a little thin. The ending, while I understand they needed to leave it open for a sequel, was just bad and no closure what so ever.

A few holes in the movie. No character build up regarding the other players.  The ending just left me empty.  Not so sure I'll watch the next one.  As always, the first one was WAYYYYY better.  Good for kids ( I think) but unfulfilling for me.

I am known fan the hunger games did see the hunger games catching fire it was not bad but was mad at the ending of the movie but if you are as fan and read books you would like the movie. I think this movie is for adults and teens
I like the movie, and liked the books.  I am not a teenager, so I am probably the oldest Hunger Games fan.  The "wedding" dress was so gorgeous, that I would watch it again just to see the dress!!
Wow! Great movie! Better then the first but also compliments the first. Looking forward to the third! Jennifer Lawrence is Amazing
Jennifer Laurence is a great actress. I personally like her early work the best . But this is good acting and good entertainment for the entire family.

Katniss and Peeta soon learn that they will never escape the strong arm of President Snow.  They and other Hunger Games Champions are called into the arena again for the quarter quell.  New alliances are formed in and out of the games.  It is a gripping story line but do not expect it to follow the book.  I love the movie and the empathetic  chatacters.  The introduction of Finnick, Johanna and Betee are important for the next film in the trilogy.  This is dystopian drama at it's finest.

Catching Fire is HOT
If you loved "The Hunger Games"
You'll love this one too.
Looking forward to having them all
Great movie follows book well! Ready for the third one now. Action pack really sucks you in. A real keeper!!!
Not as good as the book, but then what is. Great movie! I thought it was very entertaining and I cant wait to see the next two movies.
I like the fact that this movie stuck to the story line very closely and the same main characters came back to be in the second film.

I can't put it into workds.  If you've read this series or even just started with the movies you'll know what I mean.  Excellent movie!!! Jennifer Lawrence is an amazing actress!!!  Highly recommend this movie!

I absolutely love this movie.  The story is superbly written. Ms. Collins is a wonderful, imaginative, fabulous author.  I first became aware of this trilogy through my book club. Some moms were on the fence about reading it with their children, while others spoke from experience and gave opinions about reading it with their kids.  Catching Fire is Actually less violent and less gory than the Hunger Games, which is the First story in this trilogy.  Catching Fire is also my favorite of the three.  It comes down to personal preference as to whether you feel your child can handle this movie or not. However, I am here to tell you my opinion is that unless they are very sheltered children, you will enjoy this movie together.  The story is riveting, and there are many life lessons in it, which include that of love and sacrifice.  I definitely give it five stars.
If you don't know the story or have seen the first movie, you will be lost.  A little confused about ending.
I had bought the first Hunger Games movie and just had to get the second one. I must say I'm glad I did! Great movie and was even packaged neatly.
I love the books and I loved the first movie.  I was hoping that the movie would live up to the book, and it did.  Action, adventure, love, it's got it all.

This sequel to the Hunger Games has been butchered in the cutting room floor.  It views pieced together instead of fluent.  None of the characters get a chance to become beloved or hated.  I was disappointed.
Great sequel! Worth watching and it's leading into the next with a to be continued style ending. Triggers lots of emotion

Nice job!  I think they did a better job on this movie than the first one.  Full of action and really there's so much going on behind Katniss' back, that even she is taken by surprise.  Pretty violent, though so I wouldn't let the little ones watch it.
It was a great action pack movie. I am a little disappointed in the ending. But I would watch it again so that alone should tell u something.

As far as the books go, the first one was my favorite. However, I think as far as the movies go, this one is better than the first. Usually in trilogy movies, the middle one languishes between two better stories, but Catching Fire proves an exception to that rule. I found myself getting really caught up in the story even though I knew what was going to happen. This is definitely worth watching more than once!
Loved every second of it. Would recommend everyone to watch it. Story line, acting, and cinematography were definitely an A+.
I would watch this movie again. It had very good graphics and an intriguing story line. This was a great sequel to the first one.
Almost as good as the book.  Excellent character development.  This movie achieves what every movie of this genre aims to achieve.  I am considering adding it to my collection.

I hesitated watching this movie due to the violence of the first, but conceded to the recommendation of some kids who are well engrossed in the trilogy and books. So I excused myself in order to see what the fuss was about. Surprisingly, what I found was a striking cautionary tale, with a far deeper respect for humanity than is typical in Hollywood today. It is always good to see movies with elements of truth sprinkled throughout--and by truth I mean Christian truths which we all unquestionably accept today, such as the equality of all men--though the producers themselves do not realize they do this.
I loved the movie but was frustrated with how it lead you up to a great ending then left ya hangin
It followed the book to a T, just like the first one did. It was perfect, a really great movie all around.

Not much to say about item - it's a dvd and it plays.  The movie though - while most books to screen lose ALOT in the transition (Twilight)  -- The Hunger Games are in good hands and definitely are taken from the books. There are some things I've noticed missing but not a lot.

When I first read the books I loved them but couldn't help thinking that this was brutal and not really for kids.  Same with the movies - there are underlying character traits and heart but on the surface - it's teens killing teens in brutal games that change with the push of a button or the whim of the "powers that be."

I'm not a huge fan of this series. However, I found this movie more enjoyable and easier to follow than the convoluted first one, which my daughter said was not faithful to the book and not nearly as good. So from a skeptic's point of view, I found this to be very worth watching. Might even give the first one another try.
The ending is mind blowing. Great movie normally the first is always better. They did a great job on this one. Will have you on the edge the whole time.
Lots of action, mostly true to the book.  Screen writers who make that extra effort to stay true to the book impress me.
This movie was fantastic, I read the book a while ago, and the movie was actually better than the book, which almost never happens. Enjoy!!
These movies are great, especially if you have already read the book.  The suspense for the next movie is crazy.

After reading the Hunger Games books I was excited and nervous to see the movies. I worried that they would not live up to the book series. However, so far the movies are great. Exciting and thought-provoking.

This sequel was better than the first, especially since it wasn't children killing one another. The only draw back is the very end is setting up for the next movie, so the ending kind of sucked because it was left open ended. Now other than that it was a great movie. I might buy other than rent the next time. :)
Great movie! Lots of action but cliff hanger ending. Waiting on pins and needles for the 3rd installment. Psyched to see what will happen next!

We saw the movie in the theater, so of course I had to have it for my collection.  It was a great price, and I love that it has so many versions.  My son likes to watch DVDs on his laptop when traveling, we like the blue ray version for home, and I store the ultraviolet one so it can be watched on my tablet or laptop anywhere I have Wi Fi.

The whole family enjoyed this movie, that does not happen very often.
This is the 2nd chapter, you must watch the first to enjoy this one. And it is every bit as good as the first.
I held off watching the first one, because I thought it was only a bloody horrible movie about killing children. But, that is
not the case at all. Just watch it, you will not be disappointed.
Good plot good story line good acting can't wait for next one wish they would have munchkins in the next  one
The video streaming was very bad and was only able to see this movie in bits and pieces.  Due to this problem, concentrating on the story was very difficult.
Awesome! Stayed very close to the book! The ending was amazing! Loved all the costumes and the actors were on point.

Like its predecessor, this is a fantastic adaptation of Suzzane Collins' phenomenal book.  We found this movie thoroughly exciting, well acted, well produced, true to the story, and absolutely gripping.
I loved the books and the movie does an amazing job at bringing the book to life!  Can't wait for the third movie!!
The only purpose for this movie was to prep for another sequel. It was basically a re-run of the first, with little or none of the depth, and it's ending is infuriating.
This movie was nothing more than a re-tread of the previous movie.  It had pretty much the exact same plot.
I never read the books so I'm not heartbroken that they stray from the original. I enjoyed the movie as a separate entity. This one, more so, than the first.

First and foremost, good storyline taking off from the first. I love the core theme of this particular movie how the many districts saw KATNISS. A ray of hope for them even amongst the competitive themselves. But mostly love the ending as it leads, but also left you wondering and hanging really awaiting for the ultimate climax to the whole story as you can see it buildings but really don't know what it maybe, but you know its coming.
The next sequel have to be even more challenging and the storyline have to be solid in its setting the stage form the characters to bring it to life and believable within the story context I can't wait!
Great movie can't wait for the next episode. The ending left you wanting to see more. If you haven't seen it check it out.

wonderful entertaainment. Loved the dress and the extra spin at the end.
Cant wait till the next movie comes out

I was a little disappointed in the first movie, The Hungar Games, but after re-reading the books before renting Catching Fire I'm happy to say I am loving both movies!! I am now eagerly waiting for the next installment
The movie was very good.  It met all my expectations.  I would recommend it to everyone.  The cost of rental could have been a little less.

I have not read the novels these movies were based on, but I really enjoyed the first part of this saga. So, I had to indulge myself in the second act. Love Jennifer Lawrence and Petah totally came into his own.
I was mad in the first 10 minutes but the movie was good, Mixture of crying and excitement.... I hope the next one offset the loss of the fallen ones.
The story seems good and the characters are great as well.  The overall story is really starting to start to form.
I gave it 3 stars because it wasn't as good as the first Hunger Games. Now I know that a 3rd will be made and I hope it is better.
Gripping. The theme fit for adults as well as kids. I've seen it twice now and it still lingers int thoughts.
Great, wonderful  happy, sad, love, pain, fancy, dirty, suspensful, ended, began, cried, smooth, proper, fun, wet, shocking, cutting edge, movie
After the first movie, this one brings nothing new in story or acting, an average entertainment, just ordinary pass time
Good Movie, I just wish Amazon would stream in 5.1 surround instead of just stereo.  Paid for the HD version but got the VHS sound.
Basically the same movie as the first one. Really just a filler until the finale. Only good thing is it was less violent than the first.

Of course the movie is never as good as the book, because of time constrains parts have to be shortened and cut out, but the Hunger Games so far have pretty much stayed true to the book even with some of those changes.  For me Jennifer Lawrence is Katniss as I imagined her to be.  I think she does a wonderful job bringing the character to life.  The visuals, like the outlandish clothes are wonderful to jump out of ones imagination onto the screen.  Overall I am pleased with the movie adaptation and would recommend it.  Looking forward to part 3 and how they will bring it to life.
I did enjoy this movie. It had some very cool ideas and unexpected events, scene, etc. I look forward to the next one..you can tell, yes, another one is coming

We read the book series and were looking forward to seeing the movie.  Since we were unable to get to the theater, it was great to be able to rent.  If you read the books, I am sure you will enjoy this movie.

Great Movie, didn't buffer or anything. I highly recommend it.
Saves your ipad space for memory; especially when you only have 16 gigs to start with
The second Hunger Games was exciting and can't wait for the 3rd one, buy it you'll like it, I guarantee it.
It closely followed the book. It is of a different time period but a similarity to today is clearly evident.

The reviews all said that this sequel was even better than the original.  I wouldn't go that far but it is indeed an excellent and
"Catnip" does not disappoint.  In addition to all the movies, I have read all the books and I am impressed with the way that the
producer and director stayed fairly close to the books.  Not to mention, of course, that Jennifer Lawrence is a top notch talent.
The only complaint I might have is leaving the audience suspended, having to wait for the other sequels to come out which is
not exactly around the corner.  Of course, in order to extend the franchise, they also chopped the final installment into two parts
knowing that this was their last chance to keep their audience.  I would recommend buying the DVD.

I hate to "review" movies cause it's subjective... so honestly, I just like this movie.  If you like the actors in this film, you'll probably like this movie.  Scary themes... maybe not so great for younger ones.

It's a little ironic, perhaps, that watching the first Hunger Games movie made me read the second book, which was a good read. So I was pleasantly surprised when Catching Fire came out in theaters and managed to sink it's hooks into me once again. I cannot remember a single instance that the movie overlooks from the book, and the acting is superb. Perhaps one of my favorite characters is President Snow, the ruthless dictator who oversees the 12 Districts, and Donald Sutherland truly fits the part. All in all, this movie is a must-see and I give it 5 stars.
I was disappointed! I had hoped for something more. The story seemed to be lacking. The ending was a 1.
Good but leaves something to be desired ...it leaves you hanging wanting more even though it is not quite as good as the first movie  ... and there better be a 3rd
Delivers a good story without leaving out too much from the book.  I loved the books, and I'm excited for the last movie.
same as the first one lots of drama for the first half of movie, the action the second half of the show
Amazing movie best one this year...wish it had been longer I would have sit through three hours just to know what happened next.
Ending leaves you hanging. The flow of the film was disjointed. Would not recommend to anyone. Was like watching a rerun of the first "Hunger Games".
Plot was slow to develop.  Not as interesting as the book.  Characters were not developed during the games.  Action was good.
I am a fan of this series now, Can't wait for the final part. Not sure why but this movie draws me in. I normally hate things like this and those stupid vampire movies. But this one is pretty good
I'm looking forward to the next one. Will probably have to see that one in the theater as this movie was a cliff hanger.
I don't watch a lot of movies but after watching the first Hunger Games I make sure I watch the series when it comes out on demand. Looking forward to part 3 in about a year.
Hunger Games 1 was much better. Catching Fire was slow lacked excitement.  I hated the ending. One thing for certain, there will be Hunger Games 3
Loved it!!! Great movie. It felt like an hour Vs 2 1/2 hours. Intense and attention holding for sure. Highly recommended.
not as dramatically shocking as the first hunger games, definitely recommended to anyone who saw the first, now waiting on the last.
Down with the Capitol! Good stuff. Looking forward to #3. There were a few good twists and turns in this latest.

Incredible setting and acting. Just keeps getting better. Jennifer Lawrence is infinitely more attractive in this role than most of hollywood at their finest. Peeta as a character is far too common in real life- the great guy who is overlooked for the nearly empty stunner. Breadth of characters is excellent; Lenny Kravitz is perfect as the fashionista. Not sure anyone could take this role. What a cliffhanger though.  I could have screamed...
Love this movie very close to the books. can't wait for the final movie. I could watch this over and over.
If you liked the first in the series, you'll like this one... And it leaves it wide open for another!!
Great performances, great story line... Truly cannot wait for the 3rd installment. The parallels (of course) to our modern world are both frightening and sobering.
amazon prime instant video streaming is just the best! Got to watch this movie as soon as it was available within the comfort of my house :)
Not as good as the first. Jennifer's acting was not that good in this movie. Too many holes in the story.
First half of the movie is a prelude to the excited action and splendid effects. As a result of it, I grade the movie 3 stars because it was boring and slow at the beginning.
Movie sequels usually are not as good as the first one but I must say... this one was just as good.  I cannot wait until Mockingjay!
I could have just bought it at Wal-Mart and watched it a week ahead of time. What's the point of pre-ordering if it comes a week after its release date?
Not as good as the original.  Plot was rather lengthy, with a predictable outcome.  Recommend, but beware not as good as the first.

I found it difficult to get emotionally involved in this movie. I think the film would've been better served if *SPOILER* the Gamemaker wasn't revealed to be on Katniss' side right from the get go. They should've given PSH a more substantial role and let him slow burn until the end for a the big shocking twist. Instead, there wasn't any build up at all and the ending fell flat. However, I do give major props to Jennifer Lawrence for that absolutely awesome final close-up on her face. She is crazy talented.
Truer to the books than the first installment. Moves fast and is over quickly. Ends leaving you ready for the final episode.
great movie and cast-love Sutherland in this role--the FX are well done but not over-done-they don't carry the movie , they enhance it-cast is great -growing up well!
I would have given it a 5 because it is a great movie, however, I've read the book n the movie just doesn't compare to the book. But the movie is so worth watching!
My granddaughter loved this so I watched it and liked it too.  It is a clear message of good over bad without all the unnecessary bad language.
I found this movie simplistic & predictable, though the acting was good. I did not see the first one and will probably not.
Revolution is in the air. Capital City is in for a surprise. Reality will always prevail over fantasy. Conservatism will always prevail over liberalism.
It was exciting if you like the young killing each other. I probably will not watch another one. Just not for me
Jennifer Lawrence is great, and so is woody Harrelson. The story line is believable, direction and acting are superb. Must see!
Great flick, very dark (visually)  - Jennifer Lawrence is once again amazing as Katniss. Perfect casting - characters perfectly matched to the novels.

It is a great movie involving many emotions and evoking thoughts of survival of the fittest.  Coupled with love and how it can evolve even in the darkest times.  Courage and strength are portrayed while catness puts the greater good above herself.

Never had a chance to see it in the theater, so couldn't wait to download and watch it. Wonderful follow up to the original Hunger Games. Can't wait to see the final production! As expected, it doesn't have the details of the novel, but amazing to see the story played out on the screen. I'll be purchasing the DVD for my collection.
I hate to say the usual "the book was better!" But it's true here. Somehow in 2-1/2 hours they managed to leave out some key plot elements that will be important in Mockingjay.

This time that weird vib the movie had the first time is a tad more distracting. The show is interesting enough, but just a tad off from making me want to see the next one in the theatre. I'll be waiting for it to come to video also....i did not see this one at the theatre. I gave it 4 stars because i did like it but i did not love it. I would however tell others to rent it.
Super book set to the cinema stage.  Loved the first in the series and now this one leaves you gripped in yur seat wondering how it will end in the last of the series!
Watch it......you will not regret it!  No need to go into details because the whole movie was good.  The end......
Excellent movie. The original story was enhanced by the visual presentation in this movie. I thought it was excellent and I would recommend it!
Loved it, start to finish.  They did a much better job with explaining/showing what goes on in the districts and how the hunger games are used by the capital to control.

The long awaited second edition of the Hunger Games trilogy finally appeared for rental on Amazon.
Like many film adaptations of books much is left out or remains on the editing room floor.
in any case, I was pleased to see Jennifer Lawrence and the same cast of characters reprise their roles.from the first film.
If you have not read the books, this film should whet your appetite to do so. The movie only briefly displayed the terrors and challenges experienced by Kaitness and  the characters in her second games.
Great movie, ended kind of at an akward point so they can make another one. Will definitely see the next one.

Great, leaves you wanting more, it's over too fast, I did not like how this one ended, but it was a great cliff hanger.
I still liked the first one better.
I like how it was quickly available on this site.
This movie is riveting, and it stays very true to the book. The costumes are amazing. A must see movie!

The Hunger Games movie was a novelty...children learning about survival. The sequel had very little to do with children and the games were about the Capitol manipulating the games which became more about their own vengeance than the other contestants trying to survive. Donald Sutherland was wasted in this movie. In fact all the actors worth so much more were wasted in this movie.
Awesome movie.  Not as good as the book, but are they ever? Definitely a must see, but first, read all 3 books and see the first movie.
Would be 4 stars if there wasn't a first movie, this one was just kinda a rerun.  Some what disappointed

Never underestimate the power of HOPE!

I watched this movie with my granddaughters on their recommendation, and enjoyed it very much. We watched The Hunger Games first and I am glad we did because I think it was necessary for understanding. I felt they were both very intense. Looking forward to the next one!!

After reading The Hunger Games and Catching Fire, I was apprehensive and excited to watch the movie, and I was not disappointed!  It clarified what I read and I watched Catching Fire holding my breath! Very exciting and kept to the book. Excellent movie! Can't wait for the final episode!
Guess that's the books, still an enjoyable rental.  I hope the third movie has more interesting plot lines and/or content
good movie but not one I would keep in my Library. You may want too to keep in yours Library.
It was very true to book, which I appreciated. I definitely recommend watching it in HD. Looking foward to the last installment.

Catching fire is  amazingly enjoyable movie. It followed the book very closely with some minor omissions, but added some important dialog between Snow and game maker Heavensbee (behind the scene) because of the storyline is basically Katniss's pov. As we know, Catching Fire topped the domestic box office for 2013.  Although they were few negative ratings, this movie rating was excellent. Acting was superb - especially Jennifer Lawrence, Jena Malone, and Mr. Hoffman.(RIP). Last but not least , the special features in the blu ray disc was amazing.  It showed how the movie was made. For me the best segment was how the battle with the monkeys was made.

The majority of people are the other way around, but I just didn't feel anything like I felt at the first specially at the girl's death.

Starting from the scene where they take her up the plane, it just started becoming ridiculously non believable.

So they assumed she was going to cut power?

The ending was like, what, that was it?

By the way everyone keeps talking about government, us government, world government, etc...

but am I the only one who kind of sees it in a bigger level? as of this world, it kind of feels like the dome where the games occur, where things happen and everyone is just surviving and then if there's a god he's just watching.

To me it kind of hints at rebellion at that god or whatever governing power on this universe.

Maybe I'm crazy, but those are just my thoughts.
Highly recommend this movie to anyone who liked the first Hunger Games movie. Will be looking forward to the next one.

First one was great took at least an hour in the second one to get to the games and once it started getting better it was over. Really they should have done this in 2 movies that are slightly longer and cut a bunch of this one out. I will be watching the 3rd one when it releases that one should be good. Major disappointment in this one though.
this movie was so badly acted, had a great cast, and still could not pull it off like a bad day at the wonka factory. Waste of our time.
We read all the books and are now collecting the movies.  Amazon had the best price.  We will continue to reorder from them.

really enjoyed the story and the action
great characters and was better than the first (although the
1st was great). would recommend for sure
After seeing the first movie, I was hooked!  This movie was awesome! This is a must watch, you won't be disappointed.

Most of the time I would say a 2 1/2 hr movie can get somewhat tiresome. Not the case here. In fact, it only leaves you wanting more. I was surprised but I actually found this better than the first one which I thought was awesome. Sequels have a hard time living up to the first but this one does. Can't wait for the final movie.
Awesome movie! Read the books and own the first film! Excellent adaptation! Can't wait for the final installment in the series!

These books have sold super well, and having not read them, I don't know why. The movies also seem to be selling pretty well, and I can see why. The first installment was terrific. However, this second one was a little more boring. Oh, it had action all right (bows and kissing type), but the whole time I was watching this I couldn't help but feel a sense of deja vu the whole time; especially once they got up their tubes and were actually in the game and fighting it out. Some of the drama seemed like it was the same as the original hunger games, but with new words. This may have made more sense in the books, but on film it felt too much like the original. The uprising was important to the story, but inevitably the story led from hunting illegally in the woods with a love interest, to choosing who was gonna be in the games, to how do we plan and strategize, to lets show off some skill and test the other people in the game, to the game (complete with people dying, but this time in new and different ways), to her surviving. The ending makes some possible suggestion that in the final movie/book there is less of a focus on the games and more of a focus on the political climate and the impending uprising hinted at in this movie. Let's hope cause that next part is gonna be split into two movies (part one and two) this year and next and I would rather see what happens in that arena rather than the games themselves. In the meantime, I raise my three fingers and hope for the best next go around.
not near as good as the first one. didn't match up with the book either. was rather disappointing. wish i had rented first.

Catching Fire is the second installment in the Hunger Games franchise.  Catching Fire, in my opinion, is a touch better than The Hunger Games, but still not without its notable issues.  I have many of the same problems with this film that I had with The Hunger Games.  I did not read the books so I cannot make any comparisons but I did hear that they cut a lot out.

The film takes place a year after The Hunger Games.  Katniss (Jennifer Lawrence) and her friend Peeta (Josh Hutcherson), who were the victors of the last Hunger Games are on tour of all the Districts.  Everyone sees Katniss as a light of hope due to her actions in the Hunger Games.  Rebellions start to break out in all of the Districts.  The president, played by Donald Sutherland is not happy about this, because this could trigger a full-scale revolution.  He tries to get Katniss to her side.  Katniss herself does not want to be a symbol and only wishes to keep her and her family safe.  However, the president forces her and Peeta to participate in the 75th Hunger Games.  This time the victors of previous games will face off.

The first issue I have is with the first 30-45 minutes.  I personally found it a little boring.  The first 45 minutes is Katniss and Peeta on tour and her being a symbol of hope for the people while trying to please the president so he does not kill everyone in her District.  I know why it is there, but I just got a little bored after a while.  I heard in the book that plotline took even longer.  However once they announce the Hunger Games and we are introduced to the other combatants then things pick up again.  I did not find the first part of this film quite as boring as the first part of the Hunger Games.  I found the first part of the Hunger Games to drag on a bit too long and it is clich.  It was not bad, but it was too long.  Here I was less bored.

Another issue I had was the shaky-cam during the fight scenes.  I had this problem with the Hunger Games as well.  During the fights the camera moves too much and I could barely make out what was happening.  In fact I found there to be more shaky came here than the Hunger Games.

Aside from Katniss and Peeta, the rest of the cast gets very little development, like in the last film.  However, I did like the supporting cast more here and they get a bit of development, which is more than I can say for Hunger Games.  I also found that the ending was too abrupt.

However, despite all of that Catching Fire is still a good film and I do like it a bit more than the Hunger Games.  The main reason is that the story is stronger.  The Hunger Games mainly focused on introducing us to the character and setting up the world.  It mostly focused on the games themselves.  Here it focuses more on Katniss herself and her being a symbol of hope for the people.  It also deals with the inevitable revolution and introduces key characters that are relevant later.  I also like the supporting cast more.  I felt that they had more life and energy even if they do not have much development.  I also like the design of the actual games more this time around as well.  Some of the obstacles they put in are very creative.

The effects are amazing.  Again the design and obstacles of the Hunger Games itself are very well done.  I like how there is more future tech used here.  The world they are in still looks amazing.  I did not see this movie in 3D so I cannot say how good the 3D is.

Overall, if you like the Hunger Games, then you should like Catching Fire.  I did like the Hunger Games quite a bit despite everything I said about it earlier.  I did think that this was a good film as well despite the problems I had.  The effects are great, the cast is great, and the acting is on point.

(see what I did there hunger games, you know you like it)

President Snow has a dilemma.  Katniss Everdeen is so popular in all of the sectors that people are beginning to protest and revolt against the Capital in protest of their own personal treatment, lack of food and overall way of life.  They feel like slaves working for the benefit of the Capital just because they lost a war long ago.  They see Katniss' bravery and fighting spirit as the motivation to fight for a better way of life.  President Snow plans a new special edition of the Hunger Games and he hopes to disgrace and ultimately see Katniss killed in action....

This is an excellent film and the storyline is tight and well presented.  The special effects are well done and the acting is superb.  Jennifer Lawrence just does a great job in playing Katniss and she really is an acting talent and box office draw.  My family watched this film and we liked it more than the first film.  That is unusual for a sequel but in this case it is true, at least for us.

The movie ends abruptly but we all know that there is a final episode coming.  I enjoyed this movie and I recommend that you buy the DVD.  It does have a lot of replay value and it is a good story.
Looking forward to sequel.  This is syfy that can be enjoyed by the whole family.  The Hunger Games will be around for a long time.  Worth buying and keeping in video collection.

It's a solid, more substantial film that the first (more funds were clearly put into it -- but not in an overblown way.  The story was very gripping and well paced.  The only complaint I have, keeping it from getting all five stars, is that it has a very jarring end.  The pacing was thrown off as a result and the film just kind of cuts out.  I understand more are being made, but I didn't feel as if any satisfaction was provided and no third act was in the film.
