Suffers from the classic problem of all Amazon streaming movies--bad audio compression.  Action sequences are crazy loud and dialogue is a whisper.  So you pump the volume on dialogue scenes then get blown away when it switches to an action sequence. I have a Sony stereo receiver with over 40 settings.  I have tried them all in many different combinations, and have come to the conclusion that Amazon does not have any idea how to stream video.  They should take notes from Netflix.  Netflix does 7.1 surround with volume normalization and I can actually put the remote down and enjoy the movie.  Amazon doesn't care that they send out an inferior product, they don't even respond to you when you email them.

read all the positive reviews before buying the movie, which I didn't, I surely would have wondered about the way people
seemed to be writing books of praise for the movie. Conclusion: Insiders.

Visually, the movie was fun, but completely at the expense of character development. The actors looked a bit ridiculous as a result. The scene where Katniss tells Gale she can't deal with thinking of him "that way" was probably the worst delivery I've seen in years. Especially after caring for him so diligently after he was whipped and running to him with such emotion when coming back to District 12. Very uneven handling of the character and her emotional state. How could the director use this cut in the movie? Was that really the best Jennifer Lawrence could muster? And there was some real, emotional character development in the book with Katniss's relationship with the Avox, which was completely ignored in the screenplay, and could have made us care a bit more about her and Peeta. Editing--ugh. Directing--ugh.

Of course, I thought the books declined in quality as well, so if you thought all of the books were awesome, then you and I probably aren't on the same page. I doubt I can drag myself to see the whiny, self-obsessed Katniss from book three, especially if the editing and directing remains this poor.

Goof effects will never be a substitute for a well thought and worked story, which this movie in my opinion is a very good example. It might suit teenagers taste, I guess, but the whole saga and so wide open endings just don't work for me. Good actors, but a weak and trite story.

If you want to see Jennifer Lawrence doing great acting get "Winter's Bone," but she is also quite good in this.  It is pretty predictable, but entertaining nevertheless. It won't make your brain explode with deep thoughts or anything, which is just perfect for some relaxed entertainment. It will be interesting to see what they do to replace Phillip Seymour Hoffman in the next movie.

Story similar to the first: same gruff, self-sacrificing heroine, this time it is Peeta who must live no matter what, as lead experiences the bounty of loving and being loved by two fine young men; same villain, this time displaying hints of paranoid insanity (never like when the villain is insane, just doesn't work for me), a new group of killers supposedly pitted against one another in a new game. A main problem for me is film doesn't show how the rebellion got it's key players and how they're organized. Another problem is the villain: how did the rebels manage to survive the Donald Sutherland character's hyper-vigilant eye, right under his nose.  Also, don't think it's a good idea to have the lead outside the story, i.e., ignorant of the rebellion; she should be in the thick of the rebellion as the Capitol is making her life and the lives of all she knows, hell.

Because this story presented the rebellion as a fate accompli and didn't show the nuts and bolts of how it came to exist, rebellion not believable.

The film story is missing a level in the Capitol's hierarchy, the character who would be Donald Sutherland's aid, the first officer, the person who'd actually enforce Donald Sutherland's edicts.  Donald Sutherland's organization is too thinly presented here. Where are his spies, where are the citizens wanting to curry favor, and do so by presenting him with any morsel of intel? No Capitol intrigue, no Capitol competitors josling for position. Where are the ambitious characters who, knowing the Donald Sutherland character dislikes Katniss, attempt to have her killed to get into his good graces? As presented there seems to be Donald Sutherland, and the military; he appears alone at the top: isolated, old, crazy, vulnerable, cruel and ruthless - such a leader seems ripe for rebellion, but worse storywise, he's not frightening (as he doesn't even know who his own enemies are) or believable. What is the source of his power that he can hold all the presumably millions of people to a system which clearly serves so few of them? This is crucial information the screenwriter fails to provide.

As written, the Donald Sutherland character doesn't work, for me, as a villain: he's not smart - he unknowingly chooses a games master who is plotting his downfall, yet he spends his time bullying a teenager and murdering and terrifying untold numbers of citizens.  Why is he the ruler, what is the source of his power, why has he organized his world and his people the way that he has, and why is his behavior tolerated?  The screenwriter doesn't say.  The villain is paranoid and crazy, but a power mad, insane villain is lazy writing. It begs the question, how does he remain in power? And when the screenwriter provides no answer the audience disconnects.

A competent villain, someone who is frightening and intelligent, is at the top of their game. As played, I wonder why this villain has remained in power.  Why 13 districts, why some held in abject poverty while others live in luxury, what purpose that serves, and why the majority of the citizens on that world accept the system? I understand why the poor, disenfranchised do, they have little choice, but why everyone else seems to is a mystery to me. So I guess what I'm saying is the world order in the story makes no sense to me, and it's never a good thing when the story makes no sense.

Regarding Katniss she is aided time and again and in a more believable story she'd have been murdered long ago by Donald Sutherland's assassins, considering his power, his fixation on her and his total antipathy towards her.  Since apparently she's going to be the rallying point for her people, a source of hope, not a good idea storywise to have her come to the attention of her far more powerful competitor when she has little more than a bow and arrows to defend her. My sense is she's alive in this story because she's the heroine (sort of like in a Tom Cruise Mission Impossible film where the Tom Cruise character performs impossible stunts and get's perhaps a scratch and survives because he's the hero - Katniss is like a Tom Cruise Mission Impossible lead here). Film stories where the lead survives impossible odds simply because they've got top billing don't work for me - prefer better written stories. (I like Tom Cruise's work, just not a big fan of the Mission Impossible franchise because the lead is never at risk: he's the hero, he will survive. Similar problem with the Fast & Furious franchise's over the top stunts where it's impossible for two characters to be ejected from two speeding vehicles, meet in midair over a bridge and land safely. When humans repeatedly survive death defying stunts, I'm pushed right out of the story, even when the actresses/actors themselves are appealing. There's not enough appeal in the world to explain survival when an ordinary person experiencing such events would die. The leads, if they are human characters and not magical beings, simply don't have the skill set to defeat death, no matter what other talents they possess. I wish screenwriters would make their fictitious worlds operate along the same lines of reality as my world. When they don't, I'm unable to enjoy the story.)

I read the trilogy and of what I have seen of the movies so far, I feel they both deserve 5 stars. the plot has action and has a lot of social commentary, and a beware to all those who don't recognize the widening gap between the haves and have nots. The acting is deserving of the books.

Much thanks to director Francis Lawrence as he brought a lot more depth and emotion to an action oriented young adult film (though it can be fun for anyone who is mature, as it touches on many political and social themes).

The plot is something I never go over in reviews as it because redundant on a site like Amazon where plenty will tell you and it has its own description. Now for the review: Short and Simple, mind you.

Jennifer Lawrence has become one of the most well respected actors to ever rise in Hollywood at such a young age (Tom Cruise being the only one that I doubt she'll ever beat in terms of popularity and rightfully so). In this film she adds to her character and it shows that she is not treating this franchise as a money bag and rather very seriously.

The late Phillip Seymour Hoffman was excellent as per usual in this film and will be missed in the 4th chapter of this franchise. He also plays a vital role in this film so if your a fan, watch it.

The rest of the cast are solid and bring more emotion into a more emotionally driven social themed movie then they really need too, which isn't a complaint but rather a welcome for audiences.

The action is quick, yet long, but effective. The biggest and best thing about this films action sequences is they don't seem as rushed as the first, and for the most part the shakey cam "look" is gone, thankfully.

Overall if you want some romance, some action all underneath a fairly deeply themed social/political film (although the younger you are the less likely you are to understand the themes depending on how fast you mature, lol) then this is for you. All the same if you just want a big scope blockbuster, this is also for you.

What should have been an excellent adventure movie started way too slow, and then lost its gloss with unexplained and physically impossible events. The adventure takes place where the laws of physics exist with futuristic devices.

That said, Katniss Everdeen never runs out of arrows, which is reminiscent of the old western movies with six shooters that never ran out of bullets. That could have been addressed with arrows parachuted down from her sponsors.  But it wasn't. Poor screen writing, and why didn't the producers, director, technical advisers, etc., catch that flaw?

The fatal flaw was the firing of the arrow and hitting the inside of the dome to foreshadow the final impossible arrow shot. Not possible at that distance. (There is no magic element in this movie. Everything is sci fi, but follows the laws of physics.)

(Possible Spoiler) The previous flaw was compounded by the impossibility of an an arrow pulling 30 or 40 pounds of copper cable with it to the top of the dome, to provide an exciting event.  Firing an arrow with a light string attached would actually limit the range of the arrow, because of the drag and mass of the arrow. A copper cable, yet!

And, finally, the last few seconds of the movie where an old cliche is used to justify our belief that Katniss, despite all that has happened,  is filled with determination, leading to part 3 and 4 of the story.

What should have been a perfect script for a movies grossing hundreds of million bucks, was spoiled for me by the inattention to technical details.

I saw the movie when it was in the Theatres and loved it, so ordered it from Amazon.  I'm not disappointed with the movie, but the blurb on the packaging said that you were purchasing it digitally at the same time.  And specifically mentioned that it could be stored in the "Cloud"  Since when I bought the first in the series, it too was available in the cloud, and since I've bought my Kindle Fire I've watched it on my Kindle, I thought this was the same.  BEWARE!  It is not!  It is for some other program and does not translate to Kindle!  When I called to find out what I was doing wrong, (I thought  I was making a mistake in trying to activate it) they researched the program for me, and discovered that no, it did not support Kindle fire.  Because the advertising on the product was deceptive, they gave me a refund so that I could purchase it digitally, which I did, and promptly installed on my Kindle Fire.  Thank You Amazon for standing up, but warnings to others to be sure that you get a digital copy that will interact with All Devices you may have.

I was such a huge fan of these books and the fact that it took me so long to see the second film of this franchise makes me angry. I guess that's what happens when you start dating a new guy, you put the movies you both want to see ahead of your personal must-sees. But anyways, watching this movie with everything going on in the Ukraine and Venezuela just left me feeling even more moved and in touch with the story. It's simply just a story about people struggling for freedom.

The VFX and sound mixing is perfection and the cast is simply remarkable, Jennifer Lawrence just oozes with talent and there's no one better to play a "cheeky victor". I watched it two times in the same day because I simply loved it that much. My boyfriend who refused to watch these movies with me caught the end of it (crazy island scene and so on) and even said I think I just have to stop being so stubborn and watch these movies. If he can say that, it means this film is doing something right. Just to finish, this film only gives you a dose of the brilliant Philip Seymour Hoffman but he is riveting as always may he rest in peace.

The first two Hunger Games films were very good.  As a parent to a teenager and toddler it is refreshing to find a good film that does not involve cursing, sex and drugs.  This is not only a gripping tale of a young woman trying to stand up for justice, it is also a glimpse in to what can happen when government gains too much power (anyone remember Hitler, or Mao Tse Tung?)

I really loved the movie, and could tell the franchise had evolved.  Awesome scenery, action, etc.  Everything was more intense and vibrant than the first, as it often happens with budgetary increases.

It just left me hanging...which is what the middle movie of a series will often do. I knew it was going to happen when I sat down to watch it.  I just got so engrossed in the movie that I forgot about it. This film sets up the action for the next two films.  I know I'm probably going to be even more frustrated at the break between the Mockingjay films, but that's OK.  I love the series and will continue watching no matter what.  Enjoy!

For what it's worth, the majority of this movie feels like a remake of the first. First off, let me say that I am not happy with the fact that they dropped the storyline of the pin-it tied haymitch and Katniss together even more, and gave a history to the uprising-showing that it takes time for things to grow-it seriously would not have taken that much more time-and they left the whole story of how Haymitch won out-so there is a loss of depth and complexity. While the movie makes a good, uncomplicated version of the book, there is a loss of depth (as I said), and a loss of it being a cautionary tale. I also thought that too much focus was taken AWAY from Prim and her mom-this was supposed to be where we see their medical prowess-where they are -especially her mom-are truly themselves, expert and confident-they again made her mom barely able to function. I DID like, however the use of Snow's grand-daughter as a mirror of how the Capitol and the other districts viewed Katniss and Peeta-how they were ingrained as heroes and a modern-day love-story/celebrity couple-And of course, Donald Sutherland was born to play President Snow-he could not be anymore perfect of a choice (the girl that plays his grandfather isn't too bad either). I also thought that what was kind of a mish-mash in the book, the Quarter Quell Games, was very well done, and you got to see Katniss and Peeta actually get to know eachother and bond-I LOVED how Joanna was done-she was perfect! As was Mags and even though I thought that the actor picked to play Finnick was too young-he was supposed to be as old as Haymitch-he was facile enough to show that Finnick was not as silly and slimey as he seemed; especially the scenes with mags.  The bes part about this movie is that it was well done, with solid acting and you get to see most of the characters developed into complex people, and see those people develop and learn more about each other-like when Katniss tries to write the rest of the victors off as simply killers (which a few are)but Haymitch points out, and then she sees for herself, that they are people like her, just dealing (or not) with what they had to do to survive. I found the final book the least enjoyable to read and the most poorly written and kind of annoying -it was kind of a morass, so it will be interesting to see how it is done-especially into two movies.  I always thought that the FIRST book needed to be put into two movies-the first one ending with the start of the games, and the second through her coming home. but what do I know?

I saw this movie in the theatres and while it was a good movie it did not stand up to how good the first movie was.  I have read all three books and the unfortunate thing is there is some critical information left out of the movie that is an underlying part of the main plot in the books that will happen in Mockingjay.  I don't want to spoil the movie in this review by telling you two key elements that are not clear in the movie, but should have been because of the role it will play in Mockingjay, please just read the books to see if you can figure it out.  Once I explained this to a friend after the movie, she better understood the story line, but if you didn't read the books you may have missed some things that would help you better understand the movie and will play a significant role in the next movie coming up.

I adore Woody Harrelson and think he truly brings these movies to life, but then again his character in the book is the same too. The special effects are once again some of the best without looking cheesy.  The story, although either missing, or not making clear some elements, is relatively true to the book, but done in a slightly different way so the movie is not stale.  If you're looking for a long version of the arena like the Hunger Games, you may be disappointed.  But I believe that was necessary to get to some of the outside the arena information across without making the movie so long you lost interest.  I do look forward to the Mockingjay movie to see if the elements I refer to will be addressed in a different way from the book, which would be pretty cool.  Still overall a good movie and I do not regret seeing or buying it to go with my Hunger Games movie.

Before both the Hunger Games and Catching Fire came out, I will admit, I did not read the books. People say that you should read the books before seeing the movies because you won't understand the movies if not read the books. I disagree with that. After I saw the Hunger Games, I read the book. I am half way through the book Catching Fire. I read (and are currently reading) the books after to get more information on little things that confused me.

When I saw the Hunger Games, I was blown away of how great this series is. It might just be better than the Twilight Saga! The acting in both movies is spectacular. Jennifer Lawrence especially - what an amazing actress.

Both movies get 5 stars for me, without a doubt. I highly recommend both movies to anyone who likes suspense, action, and thrill. Both movies definitely get your adrenaline up and make you very excited, nervous, and wanting more. I do not recommend it to people (and children) who are sensitive to scary things and people getting killed, because in both movies there are some scenes that can be scary and graphic for children. I would probably say 13 and up is a good age, just as its rated - PG-13. I'm not sure if younger children would be able to handle it.

I also recommend you get both movies in Blu-Ray and have surround sound. I own Catching Fire on Blu-Ray and the quality of sound is spectacular. The Blu-Ray version really makes the games part of the movie sound and look amazing, considering parts of the movie take place at night.

Hunger Games: Catching Fire is a warm, human believable story with exceptional - and rarely today - credible action and survival scenes.  If there is an Academy Award for best Action movies, this should be a winner. Well acted, well written, well directed and tremendous cinematography.  Action films tend to gloss over characters but we get to see a lot of character development from a lot of people, adding a lot of depth and interest to the movie; its not about waiting for the next action scene.  We want to know more about the characters and care about their futures.

The idea that the Hunger Games are a realistic panacea for desperate people is a stretch and that bothers me throughout the movie, but if you can accept the author's world the movie makers do all they need to to give you an exceptional, fun experience.

I enjoyed this more that the first film and eagerly look forward to the next film in the series,

This movie is based on the second book of the Hunger Games Trilogy (The Hunger Games, Catching Fire and Mocking Jay) by Suzanne Collins.  This movie picks up right where the first book left off and focuses on the events that surround Katniss Everdeen's (protagonist) struggle with life under the Capitol's rule.  If you haven't read the books, no worries, these movies expertly capture the plot and draw you in without you needing to have read the books first; although, I do recommend that you at least watch the first movie (or read the first book) so you understand the post-apocalyptic world in which Katniss lives.  With that background out of the way I'll review the plot, characters and graphics (revealing no spoilers).

Plot: 5 out of 5 stars.
For those who are unfamiliar, the subject matter of the Hunger Games series revolves around the emotional turmoil of being selected to participate in games where you are pitted against 23 other people and forced to fight to the death.  It is actually a grim subject.  Parents, be prepared to talk with your children about heavy topics like death, government control and love.  I find that the topics addressed (through the eyes of Katniss) are presented straight forward, honestly and that her take on the world is actually pretty balanced considering what shes going through.
This movie is riveting!  It is similar to the first book in that it focuses on the turmoil (emotional and physical) of the Hunger Games.  It takes you through, again, the characters' reactions to the reaping and the games (i.e. lottery selection to participate in a death battle that starts with 24 people and ends with 1 victor).  Since this is a sequel to the first book, it expands on the relationship between the Capitol and the 12 districts that serve, in poverty, under the Capitol and sustain the lavish way of life that people in the Capitol live.  The whole movie gives you a sense that the world is out of sync and out of balance, with power firmly held by the Capitol who holds it over the districts and rules with fear.

Character portrayal (i.e. how close do they match the characters in the book): 4.8 out of 5 stars.
Typically, movies do not capture the protagonist's thoughts or emotions as well as the book does.  With one minor exception, I'd say that this movie wonderfully captures each character's emotions through excellent acting and stays impeccably true to the book.  The minor exception comes with some differences between how I envisioned President Snow.  I like Donald Sutherland as Snow, but he seems too grandfatherly to fully fit the role of a ruthless, purely evil albino-type of antagonist.  In the book he is portrayed as evil and smelling of blood and other sour/foul things, which is near impossible to translate into a movie.  Aside from that minor, minor detail, I thought that each character was fully developed and remained true to the book version.  If you don't care about book vs. movie details then I thought that the characters in the movie were wonderfully portrayed, displayed incredible talent in the range of emotions they captured (and this is an emotional movie that required actors to portray happy, sad, hurt, scared, betrayed, exhausted, confused and any combination of each).  I was drawn in by the acting and thought each actor and actress put on an outstanding performance!

Graphics and Scenery: 5 out of 5 Stars
This movie really portrays, through each scene, the world in which Katniss lives.  It highlights grey/dull districts and their poverty while showing the lavish luxury and brightness of the Capitol, using colors and camera angles to capture the way the Capitol holds power.  I feel like the movie perfectly captured the little details well and there wasn't a moment in the movie that deviated in any way from the book.  In fact, I felt like I was looking at (on screen) what my mind had conjured up as I read through the books on my own.  I feel like the director perfectly captured the essence of Suzanne Collins work and I wasn't disappointed by anything (which is a feat since Im usually critical of movies).  All in all, you feel like you are immersed in this futuristic world and surviving the games with Katniss.

Bottom Line: 5 out of 5 stars!  I loved this movie.  This movie touches on deep issues, like death, and focuses on the emotions most people experience when they lose loved ones or are forces to take life in a combat zone.  Yes, this movie made me cry it was too emotionally riveting not to.  Also, I feel like this movie did an outstanding job translating the book to the big screen.  Most movies Ive seen haven't done that (thinking of the Harry Potter movies and, even though I like the, the Lord of the Rings movies).  I would go so far as to say that the movie version of The Hunger Games and Catching Fire have far surpassed the book version in many, many ways and for that I highly recommend them.

First, I would like to say, I love the movie.  I read all of the books, and after (finally) seeing the movie for the first time on Blu-Ray, I really liked the movie!  My only complaint is that it was really hard to get through and skip the commercials.  Why is it, that if you buy a movie, you have to skip through all of the commercials?  I get that if you rent a movie, there would be lots of commercials, but when I buy a movie, and watch it 2 years from now, I still have to skip through all of the obsolete commercials!

that just explodes on the screen of THE HUNGER GAMES. She is the perfect Katniss. IN CATCHING FIRE, Lawrence is on fire. There is something exotic about her. It's something rare and unique and hard to pinpoint. It's not her spoken dialogue that tells the story, it's her amazing facial expressions. It is her  amazing look.
In the first film, Katniss and Peeta pulled off an amazing feat in the 74th HUNGER GAMES by both winning in a game where there can be one victor. They have earned the love and admiration of everyone throughout the land. To please their public, they create a fake romance, but trouble is brewing as people rise against their oppression. It is the "romance" between Katniss and Peeta that gives hope to the public.
President Snow is about to change the rules with the 75th HUNGER GAMES-the Quarter Quell. Although they have been promised comfort, safety and riches after winning their perspective HUNGER GAMES, the winners are all called back for the 75th games and only one can win.
CATCHING FIRE has a slow start as we see Katniss and Peeta living their fake lives as discontent fills the land. Peeta is in love with Katniss as she shows a cold ambivalence toward him. Here heart is elsewhere but is she actually hiding deep emotions for Peeta. Although the first half of CATCHING FIRE drags on, the sparks fly when The Quarter Quell is about to begin and it is breathtaking. The visual effects, the acting, the setting, the story suddenly are of the highest claiber.
It's here that Lawrence really shines. The participants are paraded in an arena in front of the excited crowds on their way to appear before President Snow. Katniss and Peeta arrive in a chariot. As they approach President Snow, Katniss gives him a lingering look of hatred and disdain that probably has never been seen on screen before. It's an uncomfortable moment between two enemies and that scene alone is worth seeing the film.
Let the games begin and alliances form as not everyone seems eager to fight to the last man or woman. It's an amazing contest with neverending twists. The writing is crisp and the acting is mesmerizing along with the visual effects. This is one amazing film.

Jennifer Lawrence was awesome in this film. Having read the books before, I encourage everyone to do so if they're wanting to get some of the gold left on the floor. Still it followed the book quite well.

Good special effects and a story that is getting darker, if that's possible, all the time.  Having Jennifer Lawrence is a huge coup here because as good as the movie is she's light-years better.  I had just watched American Hustle not long before this and found the story not interesting at all but the acting in that movie, especially Lawrence's, was spectacular.  She's simply the best young actress working today.  In Catching Fire she elevates what would already be a good movie to another level just by the quality of her acting.

So verse 2 of "The Hunger Games", for those of us who haven't read the books, is pretty much a re-visitation of the first movie, except without all of that pesky character development of all but the two "sweetheart" characters.  And even that seems stilted, with the main character caught between the man she "loves" (for some reason?), and the man she has to "be with", who even she says is probably the best person alive.  I am easily entertained by action movies, and I don't expect much in the way of plot, and so I was not much disappointed by "Catching Fire", except that there wasn't really anything new.  Same tricks, same visuals.  Same uncanny aptitude with the box.  Except for apparent inconsistencies/minor plot holes which I started seeing... such as the door to the security room on the transport train being continually left ajar, so that the main character can occasionally get "peeks" of what's going on in the real world outside.  The ending is...abrupt, to say the least.  I had several issues with the twists revealed in the final few moments of the movie, which I can't really detail here without completely spoiling them, but one thing I can say: there is no ending here to the story-line, unlike the impression after the first movie.  There is a break in the action, that is all.  So, don't expect to leave satisfied- expect to leave wanting to see the next movie, if for nothing else than closure to the story arc.

Contrived, forced, ridiculous.  What an eye-roller.  I hope the books weren't this overwrought and self-impressed.  I would have to lose some respect for some good people.  Speaking of which -- hate to say this, but a certain recently departed and beloved actor should never have sold out to this franchise.  Even his acting couldn't elevate this writing.  And all of the dramatic crying and screaming! Aren't post-apocalyptic citizens supposed to be possessed of a little more stoicism?  Ever seen 1984?  Ugh.  I refuse to watch the third one.  For real this time.

This is one of the few movies that, while in the theater,  I found myself thinking, "this has stayed very true to the book." The new characters (Beetee, Wiress, Joanna, Finnick, and Plutarch) were all expertly cast, although Finnick's accent would sometimes slip. The costumes are incredible, Effie is perfectly her Capital self, and once again, I'm so glad at how they cast Haymitch. I was a fan of the books and am a fan of the movies.

Freedom is not to be taken lightly.  It affects every part of life as is seen vividly in this movie.  Parents, if you allow your children to watch this, watch it with them. It is graphic and yet demonstrates the point that we do not turn a blind eye to evil.

The acting is good and the cinematography is very good. The scene with the monkeys was scary, but that's it. Worth a rental, that's all.

We loved the movie Catching Fire, but it was very difficult to watch on Amazon Instant Video. At least 9 times during the movie, the video paused and buffered. Often we would have to back out and reload to continue watching. Really ruined the whole experience.

While the premise sounds far-fetched at first, the story-telling is masterful, and the film does a great job of being true to the book.  I find myself going over some of the scenes in my mind days after I watched the movie.
Much better than the first film, which was not very good at all. Jlaw gives a better performance in this movie than in American Hustle, the film she got the Oscar nom for.

Just so very disappointing,

Great movie I think it was better than the first one. Definitely going to purchase it. My kids loved it also.

The only downside to this movie is the math you have to use to figure out how many times you can watch it in one day. Oh and just so you know: if you start at 8am and stop at 9pm (factoring in food and bathroom breaks) you can watch it about five times a day.

This movie is just lush. Going from the Third World Mad Max slums and concentration camps of the districts to Capitol is like an Anti-Communist propaganda film of North Korea. Only the difference in wealth isn't as vast. The costumes are mind blowing. Even the white FN P90 machine pistols made an impact. They totally botched making Jennifer Lawrence look like a kid. Too sexy. Donald Sutherland as president Snow is the creepiest character since Hannibal Lecter. The script isn't the greatest but the book kind of goes dodgy at the end so they didn't have much to work with. Not quite 5 stars.
I watch a lot of movies and like to collect all the worth while ones. This is a good one to have and arrived on time and  in great condition

They're doing it like the Harry Potter Finale by making a double movie and splitting it in the middle. It's like watching half a show, then you have to wait a year or 18 months to see the finish. The movie would have been ok except for the way they cut it off. That part stinks.

can't wait for the next of the trilogy series..
jennifer lawrence delivers yet again
i'd say the rest of the cast fits in great but their characters don't fully develop throughout the storyline (with the exception of "pee tah")
slow start but a great flick - would definitely recommend!
I loved the first one so when Catching Fire was in theaters, I had to go see it. I loved it then so I had to see it again! Need to buy this.....

I don't think I have to tell anyone who saw this movie how great it is, however, if you haven't seen it or the first one, I implore you to take the time and the money to see it. While I pray we never ever have to use these methods to try to control a people, it certainly gives one food for thought. In the last days there will be famine and pestilence. We can learn much from these movies if we will but watch them with our eyes, but listen to them with our hearts. Enjoy! I certainly did. I don't condone violence by any means, but, violence has always been and will always be until the Lord returns and sets up His kingdom on earth.

I loved the books and was one of the first in line to the first movie when it was released.  I liked the movie, but didn't run to be first in line for Catching Fire.  I waited until it was rentable on Amazon Prime.  It's very hard to like movies based off books because inevitably something is changed.  The Hunger Games was pretty close to the book, but Catching Fire was even closer.  I've heard some people say the movie was better than the book.  I don't know if I'd go that far, but I will say that it was as good as the book.  It certainly made me want to be first in line for Mockingjay when it comes out in theaters.
I love the fast delivery with this movie. My favorite movie series next to Star Wars. I would highly recommend this series to all of my friends.

Why would they make us pay for another 16 minute preview of "Divergent" at the end?
It was a silly ending and a slow start only to wind up with another hunger games-like preview. bleh.
I'm tired of movies that quit for the sake of another sequel. No ending to speak of. Not holding my breath for the next one. Saw all this in the last one.
We enjoyed the movie. My daughters liked the movie and they enjoyed and had fun.  This is entertaining movie.  I would be recommend to watch this movie.

This movie was phenomenal! It exceeded my expectations by miles. The main actors, Josh Hutcherson and Jennifer Lawrence, were even better in this film than they were in the first Hunger Games film. Two years I had been waiting to see this movie, and it was well worth the wait!

As with the first Hunger Games film, not all parts of the book could be included in the movie, and some things were changed. I think that the biggest or most obvious change would be the reason why the Head Peacekeeper whipped Gale. In the book, it is because he was caught hunting illegally, but in the film, it was because he interfered with a Peacekeeper who was trying to harm another citizen for breaking a rule. Gale is certainly not my favorite character, but I gained respect for him in that moment of the film because what he did, knowing that he would be punished severely for it, was a very unselfish thing to do.

Sam Claflin was perfect for the role of Finnick! He made the 'beautiful darling of the Capitol' truly come alive. Seeing Sam as Finnick made me appreciate and love his character even more, and now I am dreading what might be done to him in the Mockingjay films.

I also loved the subtle humor in the film. I couldn't believe it when Effie pointed out mahogany when she was inside President Snow's mansion! A very small yet amusing reference back to the first Hunger Games film. And when Plutarch Heavensbee was introduced to Peeta and Katniss as 'the successor to Seneca Crane' and Peeta said "that's a tough act to follow!" I had to laugh! I had not expected a comment dripping with sarcasm but at the same time dripping with truth to come from Peeta.

Once again, this film exceeded my expectations, and now it is going to be very difficult to wait to see the Mockingjay films! The film truly made the amazing Catching Fire novel come alive. I truly enjoyed seeing the elements of the novel brought to life on screen.
It followed the book pretty closely, which I liked. The acting was okay. Always enjoy Donald Sutherland in president Snow. Entertaining, but not great.
Awesome,waiting for the third installment! Im wondering what special effects they'll have and how the love triangle will turn out.
Love the series. Great movie. Finished with asking wife when the next one comes out. Can't wait for next one.
The rest was boring.  Mom hated the books.  Was not a fan at all and I love the whole zombie apocalypse.  The hunger games was far more dystopian then zombies ruling the world.

All this movie does is give Hollywood another shot at more money. This is not the end of the districts, only the middle. When a movie ends and leaves you with wondering how the next movie will turn out, is pure profit for the movie makers. This movie is just part 2 of 5 movies soon to come to a theater near you. Plus is Jennifer, she is awesome. Want to leave the theater wondering what happens next? Watch this one.
Excellent!  Powerful cast.  True to storyline of book.  The left out parts did not diminish the story. The many subplots move along well.

Sit for hours in front of the screen no much happen, and the end SUCKS, the end of the movie feels like if you go to a restaurant and don't get served, or like if you go to the beach but never get there, or like .....
I thought they did a good job turning the novel into the movie.  The screenplay worked well.  They had to add some stuff into it so it is not just how Kat sees what is going on.

Catching Fire was a good movie! However I really hated how it ended! Soooo if u hate it when they leave a movie wide open for part 3!! Don't watch it!! Wait for part 3 then watch them together! I was mad!! Lol!

Again, the hungar games is a modern gladiator type movie.  It's rating is to low for the violence it portrays.  The movie is good, the acting is good, but we have enough problems with teens and young adults that lack mental toughness.  These books and movie are targeted to preteen and teenagers.  Again, a good movie, with good actors, just a wrong rating.
It was a good story.  It used the latest in technology.  It should be included with the best films of the year.
Great movie and I recommend it.  Looking forward to the next installment.  Read the books and the movies certainly do not disappoint.

I liked the first one better but this one has to build the story first before the action starts.  I didn't like the ending but it reminds me of the second Star Wars (#5) movie I didn't like it until I saw the third installment and I imagine that was the point of the ending for this one.  Dont know if it was a good enough ending to make me want to watch the third and final episode., but having the first two I probably will buy it just to complete the series...

It is sometimes difficult to follow-up a winner of a movie with a winner of a sequel.  In my opinion, Catching Fire didn't rise up to meet my expectations.  Don't get me wrong, it's an OK movie and for the most part follows the book.  As for me, I would have enjoyed a bit more character development within the ally groups.  I also found Catching Fire did not hold my interest as well as the original Hunger Games.  But, yet again, Steven Tucci's over-the-top portrayal of Caesar Flickerman brought several smiles to my face, as well as an occasional out loud laugh.  Having higher hopes for Mocking Jay...

Let's say that I love how this film reflects the truth about our society and possible future.  It shows how the athletes, actors and all media/TV personalities are nothing more than paid by the powers that be and must do what they are told or lose their standing, wealth or even their lives.  It shows how the poor celebs and athletes can get taken from the slums to entertain the rulers, but can never really retire unless ordered to.

This film, and the previous one have this odd world where homosexuals and transsexuals are running the popular society while those who are not, control it all.  That mirrors real life!  If it becomes THIS explicit in the near future - you can sign me up for an armed rebellion!  This film also shows how FEAR is used to keep people in control - that is the ONLY way that so few can rule so many.  In this film as in real life, the rulers often use fear at will when they feel paranoid and think that they are losing control in order to keep others in line.  They never let the people live in peace or rest easy - as in real life.  It is as if they are in prison and they must be harassed 24/7 - as in real life.  For this depiction of reality - I commend this film.

Now, as far as the FILM itself goes - we all now how it would play out before even watching it.  Heroine engages in threat, then faces adversity, then triumphs.  It's the same story in every action film  We all know that the star never dies, so we can predict the ending.  Without giving it away, clearly another film is on it's way and it should play out much like "Return of the Jedi" or "Return of the King."  It is the same story about tyrannical rulers, then the people wake up and arrest their fears and triumph - until the next batch of maniacs come.

At 2:36, this film was about 45 minutes too long!  After the first 45 minutes - I was wondering where they were going and almost too bored to care any longer!  I then broke away and decided to watch the old "Staying Alive" film again.  Sad to say, but I found more joy in that film than in this one!  Once I came back to Catching Fire, I was still bored but determined to see it through.

I never did like the cinematography of these films, they look like cheap 80's B movies to me.  Nothing looks modern.  The eccentric drag queens looked totally 80's and nothing about this film looked 2013 to me.  The story was not deep, they characters not deep and I never understood the idea about having teams on a last man standing, kill everyone in site competition.  I suppose this was done in order to attempt to have some character interaction with each other, although I would have preferred a "First Blood" type of film instead, it would have been more believable.

Of course they needed an excuse to put Jennifer Lawrence back in the game and I hope there is not a game in the next one.  Other than the game itself, there is nothing interesting about these films.  It is like the first - Katniss is in a last man standing competition - everyone knows this but for some reason they seem to want to help some people by killing others in order to save them.  They do this knowing that only one can survive, which is kind of pointless.  I guess they needed something to keep it going.  Also, the poisonous fog was funny.  Lawrence is in and out of sleep, then she sees the fog and decides to touch it.  It burns her leaving blisters on her skin.  Then she wakes everyone and they begin to run, outrunning the FAST MOVING fog.  Then they become surrounded by the fog, but the fog pauses, giving them enough time to talk and decide what they need to do, then the fog picks up again!  They could have left that foolishness out of the film.

I never read the books - maybe they are more exciting, but I cannot understand how the books and these films are very popular.  The story is not that deep.  I like Harry Potter a lot better and I did not think that story was all that deep.  Maybe I should write one of these types of books to see how much I can make!  I will of course watch the next one just to see it and to see what they do with Hoffman's character since his part was going to be bigger in the next film.  All and all, this was boring!  This sleep therapy film did not stop it from making $500B+ dollars in the US alone.  I think it may still be in the theaters too.  Ah well, money is money...

I applaud the director for capturing the book so well.  He was nearly spot-on, without leaving out small important details, such as the red-haired mute woman in their dining hall in the Capitol.  Even though they didn't give her much camera time, she is a foreshadow for what's to come.  The director continued a solemn feel, like the first director, only he added small details for the purpose of Katniss' feelings toward her new life.  He changed her hair color and added hallucinations, which just adds to your hatred for the Capitol.

The dvd was shipped  quickly. The Series itself is a great one. The director is brilliant. The scenes are awesome. I keep watching Catching fire all over again. I will end up buying the whole trilogy. I love the UV digital copy I can take it on the go anywhere.
Can't wait for the next movie!!! They did a great job capturing the book in this one, the next will be awesome
this is a great movie. it does a good job continuing the story while provider great intrigue. I am looking forward to the remaining two movies.
It was not as good as the 1st one. It was somewhat boring and dragged. It did not measure up.

Very slow start and really couldn't follow till the middle when things started to come together, a little.
Possible spoiler alert:
Not  a fan of the very abrupt ending.  Left you hanging.
I definitely had fun with this movie it and was well worth renting. If you liked the first one then you'll definitely like this one as well.
This is a nice sequel to the first movie and once again it leaves asking for more.  Effects are great and the story is very good.  Looking forward for the next one!
Awesome movie. Can't wait to see the 3rd one! The ending to catching fire leaves you wanting more! Loved it!
Excellent movie, especially with such a strong female lead. Great story, can't wait for the final one to come out!!

I really enjoyed the books and as usual the books are better then the movie but this is a tough movie to bring to life considering the nature of the movie but they did a good job waiting for Catching Fire

This one was a bit better than the first movie with more action overall, even in the parts where they were just kind of talking to everyone you could tell there was a lot of fear, tension, and anger which kept it from getting too boring.

The biggest issue I had with the movie wasn't even part of the story, but more with the overall director and how scenes had inconsistent details. When they were in the arena and Katniss had the bow and arrows, at every fight she emptied her quiver and it even showed it empty, then the next scene she would have them completely restocked magically. Also in the scene where they were chased to the shore by the baboons Finnick's spear was for some reason a fraction of the size as it was in all the other scenes. (just 2 examples, I could make a list of probably 50 if I took the time to type them all out).

I mean if stuff like that doesn't bother you then you'll love this movie regardless whether you've seen the book. Personally I've never read the books, I just enjoy movies like this. I rated 4/5 not because of the story but because of the inconsistency in scene details.
Enjoying this series so far.  I think this was better than the first one.  I am looking forward to the next one.
Great cast! Funny, suspenseful, thrilling and stunning visuals. 10+ stars of I could rate that high!! I definitely recommend this movie to anyone!!
Dont panic if it does not follow the book, but it still tells a great story of Katniss and her wars with the capital.
I would recommend this movie. I almost thought it was better than the book. I am looking forward to number 3.
Awesome movies available to stream before we could get it on DVD. Continuing with the story and leaving you wanting more

I thought it would be average for a sequel. Especially when I saw it was 2.5 hours. I was pleasantly incorrect. It wasn't GREAT, but it was pretty darn good! I didn't care for the ending but... meh. I was happy all in all.
This movie was excellent.  The suspense kept you hooked and I won't ruin the ending but I will just say you must see and will enjoy.
Very good sequel to the first hunger games.  There will be more to come after this one and with no fowl language I will be sure to watch them all.
The second sequel to the Hunger Games saga is good.  It follows the book fairly close.  My teenage granddaughters really enjoyed it.

The Hunger Games: Catching Fire was a fantastic second installment in this series. The end leaves you wanting more, and hopefully the next movie will be just as great. Love the fact you can watch the first one on Amazon Prime for free and then follow it up by renting the second.
This movie kept more entertained for the entire length of the film. Great movie, I would say it is a must see.

It was a bit long and the ending just plain sucked. I don't like the style of movie that wants to draw you in for a sequel - so I guess it will work, Jenni is amazing and beautiful makes it all worth it.

I liked The Hunger Games so I rented Catching Fire thinking it would be a good movie. I was only slightly off, its a great movie. If you like the first one, this one will definitely make you a fan. Its funny because you see a lot of these young adult book series being made into movies and even television, but I've found that a lot of the time, and especially this time, these movies are filled with good drama and deep characters. I just find it a bit surprising since they are based on young adult novels, pleasantly surprising. Never underestimate a movie. You may just get really lucky and watch something really good.
Disappointing plot line, confusing at times and pointless. Too little of anything to keep my interest and make me want to see it again.

I preordered this movie on the Sunday before it came out (that Friday). We aren't expected to receive this until Monday. What a disappointment the shipping was. I believe this is because I am not a Prime member. Preordered movies should be delivered by their release date and I am not far from a shipping center. My wife planned this movie night and thought that by preordering 5 days in advance it would give her one less errand to run (go buy the movie at a brick and mortar). Really ruined our plans. I don't use Amazon enough to justify prime, but I'll have to do the free trial next time we want to preorder a movie. Lame.
We loved this movie!!! Ready for the next installment! Great action and plot twists! This one was as good ad the first!!

I am a book worm, this movie left so much out. I understand that for time purposes and what not they shorten things that aren't essential to the story...for me everything is essential.  I always try to not hold the movie to such high standards b/c none of them are ever as great.  The acting was superb, the cinematography was great...the story was just rushed.  To rate this poorly wouldn't be fair just due to my high expectations.  I am disappointed that some things were left out, for example: In the book Plutark shows Katniss a pocket watch at the end of tour party.  I felt this was VERY important to the story and it would have only taken 5 seconds to show. Bonnie and Twill? Not mentioned.  The Bread in the arena? Nope again. Also, I don't feel they portrayed the injuries as much as they should have.  Overall the movie was good.  I have read Catching Fire at least 5 times, so like I said my expectations were unbelievably high.
Same plot  no excitement and it was disappointing to see less action then the first hunger game it dragged to long

I enjoyed the first film and expected more from this one.
The story was weak and poorly executed.
The abrupt ending is disgraceful.

Some of the visuals are pretty good, as well as some acting.
One good thing is that I have been forewarned about the next part of the series, and so I will save some money.
This is a great movie from the series.  Can't wait for #3.  The whole family loves it.  It is a fun series.
the storyline just went down hill. the character is so angry or mad all the time. thats just my personal prefrances. the fighting scenes were great. but i just don't like the way it ended

Jennifer Lawrence was the fire of this movie. I loved the action and the emotional balance. Although the movie is not precisely following the book; it is nonetheless an excellent telling of the story. You will not be disappointed when you view this film.
Disappointing lead in to a 3rd movie. This story line could have had some depth about the characters from each district.

I admit I didn't have much hope for this movie.  I've read the Hunger Games trilogy.  I liked the first book best, and the third book was pretty good...but the second book I really had to force myself to complete it.  Its one redeeming feature were the likable characters.

The movie managed to take all the major points of the second book and make a well paced movie.  There was a brief point where it felt a little long, but overall it didn't lag.  The characters were just as lovable.  Jennifer Laurence is a little less wooden in this movie, which makes her more appealing.

Although Catching Fire is well done and provides a good transition to the final installment of this series, I didn't think it captured the emotional energy of the book. Particularly, the apartheid between Capital City and the districts as well as the emotional turmoil of Catniss. Actually, the depth of almost all of the characters was lacking.
I really enjoyed Hunger Games, Catching Fire is just the right follow up and is as good as the first or better. I am 72 but still enjoy a good movie.
Catching Fire is tense and entertaining.  At the same time, it gives us a glimpse of a dark future that may be all too near.

The cast, the story, the look of this film. All capture the book its based on far more than Jackson's overblown Hobbit. (I'm actually hoping that in ten years, someone will do a GOOD version of the book, say a three hour version, rather than an unneeded 9 hour one). Jennifer Lawrence is, as usual amazing and the film just grabs the viewer and flies with them. Well worth seeing and more than once.

I really enjoyed how they did the story line of this hunger games. I did not expect it to end the way it did. I cannot wait for the next installment. I had to watch it again just to see what I missed. People will enjoy this movie for years to come!
I really enjoyed watching this movie. I think it was better than the first movie and can't wait for part 3.
This follow up to Hungar Games keeps you on the edge of your seat.  You don't know what is going to happen until the end.  Great movie and RIP Phillip Seymore Hoffman!
The Books are Definitely More Captivating.  Movie Was Slow And Dragged Out. I Was Actually Bored, Watching This Movie. :(
Great follow-up to the first film!  Great storyline and will keep you guessing until the very end.  Greatly enjoyed viewing this film.
The story seemed rushed and incomplete. Understand it is part 2 of 3, but the movie felt like it was in a hurry to end and leave the audience hanging just to setup part 3.
Great series. Jennifer Lawrence is great in this movie. The plot is very intriguing and captivating throughout. Definitely recommend to others
All I can say without a spoiler to those who have not watched is the ending completely opened it up for a sequel.  Good Job!

I really like this movie and i also liked Hunger Games but i love the books so much nore. The actors in the movies are amazing its the story that is lacking but Catching Fire is the better of the two movies!

Great movie and follow up to the first one. Now I have to wait all the way until November to see the next one :(

Will have to watch again, as I was knitting. Need to pay attention to all

Loved it. They did a great job taking a long book and bringing it to a movie that is true to the authors vision.  Can't wait for the third movie.
My biggest gripe with the movie is that it ended too early.  I wanted MORE!  It is obvious that another sequel is in the works.
Loved this movie I felt it was more true to the storyline of the book the visual effects were stunning.
I love this entire series. The sequel did not disappoint. I was on the edge of my seat the whole time.
This movie had my stomach in knots! And I loved it! I think you will love it too. So watch it.
As a person who reads the books before the movie, the adaptation from book to screen is always nerve-racking. However, Catching Fire was fantastic on so many levels! A must watch!!!
It was awesome. Great special effects. Magnificent acting. The movie has you at the edge of your seat the whole time they are in the the game. The ending is amazing and leaves you wanting more!!
The story and special effects were very good. It did end rather abruptly leaving everyone hanging for the third movie.
I was much happier with this film than I was with the first. The film is much darker and the characters are better developed. Well done.

Much better than the first of the series, this one felt more in line with the book but they still left a lot out. But what movie does not when converted from a book. Its a great movie, if you like the books definitely watch this one.
Great movie! Very intense from beginning to end. It surpassed all expectation that I had from watching the first one.

These movies deliver in every way possible! I'm not expecting the next film to be any different. I really enjoyed the original Hunger Games movie because it was so un-Hollywood, but this second installment is the exact opposite. Yes, it's slicker, bigger, etc, but for me that's the problem. After a good first half developing the ideas from the first movie in a darker and wider context, the second half is plain silly, just one CGI action scene after another. In the end I no longer cared for the characters, which is a shame because I think this series had more potential. No doubt my opinion will be in the minority, but 20 years from now I bet the original movie is far more valued than this one will be.

This film is a continuation of the semi-interesting "Hunger Games."  The original film was a rip of "The Running Man" and "Logan's Run."  Since the first film was so successful (although I couldn't see why), I decided to rent the sequel.  I thought, well, it's bound to be distracting at the least.  It wasn't.  It added nothing to the original film in terms of originality and even lost points because it just re-purposed a hackneyed concept.  The first half of the film is excruciating.  Nothing (I mean nothing) happens other than as a predictable set-up for the second half, which was just a less exciting recycling of the first movie.  With judicious editing, the first half of the film could have been reduced to about 12 minutes.  After the second half was completed, you are left with nothing but a teaser for a third film.  At that point I felt that this whole enterprise might have made a second-rate mini-series for TV.  The only positive thing I can say is that I think that Jennifer Lawrence has actual talent.  She under-plays her character in a professional manner, and has the look and style of an actress who needs a better forum to show off her abilities.  Otherwise, save your cash and just buy a bag of Doritos.
Get as far as the idoitic DTS screen, then everything freezes.  It won't play.  Can't be the hardware, as every other blu ray new release purchased as recently as this week plays just fine.
Great movie but it froze several times making our first viewing experience less enjoyable. We had to wait for the whole system to reboot each time.

I won't go into any details of the movie itself as most people have seen it themselves. I love this movie & feel that it's a fantastic follow up to the first Hunger Games. The story is fantastic & pulls you into it leading up to the games. The picture, action & 7.1 sound are flawless. My one & only complaint is the multiple aspects ratios. I love the stunning 2.40:1 presentation & I wish that the Blu-ray offered this option to view al the way through the movie. For those of us with a 2.35:1 cinemascope screen for a home theater the switching aspect ratios are a pain in the butt. I wish that the viewer could choose to watch the entire movie in the 2.40:1 aspect ratio or the switching version. On my 80" flat panel it makes no difference but on my 148" 2.35:1 cinemascope screen in my theater room I hate that it switches back & forth. There are several other movies that do this & they are all hard to enjoy. Why don't the studios follow what the fans of home theater like? I'm not sure.
Watched the first one and liked it but this one is such a disappointment.  So boring, I had to take a few breaks in order to finish it.  Didn't like the way they did the ending.

Okay movie.  Fun in spots.  But Part 2 was mostly uneventful and shallow.  Sure it has some great visuals and action here and there, but it severely lacked flow, cohesion, and a proper intellectual plot.  It was far too simple and so predictable.  I could guess most conversations before they talked.  No real surprises.  More of a Class B or C mindless movie, you watch it and say okay that was fun BUT where was the beef?  And the ending?  None.  You realize instantly at the end, what this little movie was really all about.  It was just a big set up for the future Part 3 that surely will come.  And it probably will be called Hunger Games Part 3, the Revolution.  I guess Part 2 was "filler."  At the end of Part 2 you can see the determination in Jennifer's eyes.  She's mad and not going to take it any more.  Part 3 will have her as the centerpiece and leader of the revolution.  Part 1 was okay and now Part 2 was okay as well.

Again Part 2 was fun but not deep.  Ideas not developed or connected between or within scenes.  But then again, I sometimes like brain dead movies that are fun.  Much like space invaders or pac man, just enjoy them for what little they have to offer.  As long as you don't expect much, you won't be too disappointed by Part 2.  No matter how disjointed its storyline is.  It just does not flow well.  But the monkey fight was entertaining for the short time it existed.  Along with the lightning and the acid fog etc.  Little snippets thrown in to keep you from getting too bored during the movie.  Characters were shallow and relationships too thin.  Acting was okay but nothing outstanding, mostly vanilla people going through the predictable motions to get to the end.

If anything, Part 2 was giant trailer prelude to hopefully a better future Part 3.  Hopefully with a plot and closure.
Loved this movie - I didn't know I got 1 DVD, 2 blue Ray DVD and the digital copy - so that was a nice surprise!!

Catching Fire was a fantastic film - a big improvement over The Hunger Games.  I can't add any more to the virtues of the film, so I'll focus on the Blu-ray features.

Don't get excited for the deleted scenes.  They last less than 5 minutes, and the longest one is a very slightly extended version of a scene in the film between Snow and Plutarch.

The Making Of feature begins with director, producers, and actors discussing the pressure to create a sequel that would be a worthy follow-up to the success of The Hunger Games.  There were interesting little tidbits, like a parking garage that was converted into the set used in the scenes where the tributes train.  Also, I knew that much of the arena filming was done in Hawaii, but I did NOT know that the Cornucopia scenes were filmed in Atlanta.

In another feature, the cast talks about their admiration for each other.  Philip Seymour Hoffman was featured, and listening to everyone talk about how happy they are that he joined the series was quite sad.  Other features focused on the weapon training for the cast, costumes and makeup, and preparations for the filming of Mockingjay.

The acting is of course superb, and the story line is wonderful.  The only reason I gave it four stars  and not five is because I was peeved at the abrupt ending lol.

(Sorry I have never read the books and don't feel like looking up the spelling of their names.) Catniss and Pia are back home. They have to go on tour to all the districts to show off that they "won". It is hard as of course as the people in the districts have had one of their own murdered, and of course Catniss and Pia knew some of the slain. Anyway, they have to pretend that they still are in love with each other and will have to always do that. But the president is still smarting over their ability to stay alive. So he plots. He sets up the games so that the victors of each of the past games has to fight each other instead of new people being chosen. So Catniss and Pia are heading back to be contestants of the games to fight to stay alive again. But before they do and while they do people are starting to get empowered by Catniss and Pia's last win. The capitol is even deployed to crack down on it.

But what you see is not what you get. Is everyone trying to "surpress" the uprising/revolt? Or are they trying to stoke the flames? I won't spoil it for you. YOu'll have to see for yourself. But this movie kinda let me down. Instead of developing characters and such it was just developing the larger plot that this miniseries of movies is going to unfold. So you had to see the first to get this movie. And this movie didn't give you much except to draw you in to make you watch the next one. It reminds me of the second to the last Twilight movie. It gave you nothing new and demanded you return for the last one which barely gave you anything but an ending. Instead of people trying to make money make some entertainment. Anyway we know that the next fallen druggie Hollywoodite who had a pretty hefty part in this movie--Hoffman--won't reappear. So it will be interesting how his irresponsible behavior throws this movie a curve ball too. I mean . . . when you watch this . . and see the ending of the movie . . . you realize his death by reckless behavior left a big hole in it.
Unfortunately i had forgotten how BAD the first movie was. This was no different. At least i was able to stay awake during this one.

I am giving this movie five stars. It is PERFECT!!! I do not regret my decision to buy this movie. It is just fantastic. But there is one problem I have, not with the movie itself, but with the way the movie is shown. The first two thirds o the movie is shown in very nice widescreen blu ray, but the last third of the movie suddenly goes into fullscreen. I know that this part of the movie was shot in imax, but honestly I would just prefer widescreen because it gives the movie a cleaner look. The last third just felt sloppy. I started off by watching the original Hunger Games movie. At that time, I hadn't read the books. After watching the original film, I was anxious to see where the story would go and knew I couldn't wait for the second film to come out.

So, I began reading the leftover novels. I have long since finished both books, but I was still left anxious to see the movies. Thankfully, Catching Fire has finally come out on Blu-Ray!

Having read the book and watched the movie (both more than once), I can say that the film did a phenomenal job portraying Collins' fantastic novel. From the amazing music, to the genius acting, they nailed it.

(Semi-spoiler alert) Now, some might complain the film ends on a cliffhanger. While this is more proof as to how true to the book they were, it can also be frustrating to those who haven't read the book. Which, ironically, is exactly what can be done to solve the issue. Read the third book, no more spoilers!

I'd recommend the book to anyone with a craving for The Hunger Games (pun intended).

The Hunger Games 2 Catching Fire was really a good movie although I like the first one best. There were so many questions at the end of movie that it left us confused. I am guessing they will come out with a Hunger Games 3 that will answer all of those questions , I certainly hope so!

If I wanted to go see Divergent, I would. Being FORCED to watch a trailer is BS especially when the movie looks like crap.

Otherwise, I loved this movie. I think Francis did a great job translating Catching Fire from written text to a movie.

It's rare that I think a movie outdoes its book ( the only other case that comes to mind for me right now is The Horse Whisperer) but this one definitely does...it captures much if not all of what was really good about the book- and outdoes it in terms of retaining one's interest and empathy for the main characters. In particular the actors playing the lead males give these characters dimension that they didn't really have (for me at least- and I read the book twice) in the books
This movie had so much sadness mixed with anger. Jennifer Lawrence is definitely a "girl on fire" and I can't wait for the next movie to come out.

In this 2nd installation of the Hunger Games, Katniss Everdeen and Peeta Mellark become targets of the Capitol after their victory in the 74th Hunger Games sparks a rebellion in the Districts of Panem.

When the first Hunger Games came out, I wasn't at all familiar with the book or the story that it was based on, so I wasn't really sure what kind of movie I was going to get.  But after watching it, I was very impressed with the story that the movie told, actually interested me in reading the books.

With that being said, I have looked forward to seeing the second installment of the movie series.  This is definitely a worthy sequel to the original and in some ways is better than the first.

Although the movie focused around the games as did the first movie, that didn't hurt this sequel at all.  Catching fire manages to provide more character development and depth for both Katniss and Peeta.

Both Jennifer Lawrence and Josh Hutcherson do an excellent job like in the first of bringing the characters from the book to life and In addition Woody Harrelson, Donald Sutherland and Philip Seymour Hoffman all do an excellent job in their respective roles as well.

The action is solid, the story as good as the first and the characters both old and new keep you interested throughout.  Catching Fire is definitely a worthy sequel and worth watching.
I loved the books and the movies are one of the vew that do it justice. I loved this movie and cant wait for the next one.
This very closely followed the book and was well put together. Pre purchase was awesome, I was refunded the difference in price since the price dropped and it arrived the day it was released.

This is an awesome movie. It is even better than the first movie. The price is excellent and it arrived on the release date. I did not have to leave my home and drive to a local store. I highly recommend this blu ray.

First the grain of salt, I've broken my ankle and I'm two weeks in bed right now. I've read and watched my full repertoire....pain has definitely made me a bit weepy, but this was a cunning and skillful rendering of the book. The necessary detail cuts that generally leave me grinding my teeth after movie adaptations were well chosen and beautifully filled in by a subtle, crafted performance by Phillip Seymour Hoffman and let's call it....the rest of the cast....well, I was a bit verklempt in several places. This captures the essence of the novel and strikes the perfect chord. My daughter was right when she was distraught (not the only reason) about the loss of PSH....I don't envy the person who may have to attempt to replace his performance. Make no mistake, this movie is much grittier and harsher than the first one and relievedly so....this doesn't glorify violence but it doesn't try to redeem it, disguise it or flinch from it as I felt the first film did. Folks appalled about children killing children....get over it....it's not gratuitous....it's about the nature of Tyranny, oligarchy and the corruption of absolute power......that's the ENTIRE point of the book, the film. Fans of the series....this didn't disappoint for me on any level.

If you enjoy children killing children then this series is for you.  Where are we as a society that we are endorsing and watching movies depicting horrific violence on teens?  Regardless of the violence being wrapped up in an incredibly average plot it's still kids hurting kids.  You need to evaluate your life a little if that equals enjoyment for you.

I just received this today--a day early (Thanks Amazon and FedEx Smartpost!). To clear up any misunderstandings that other reviewers have complained about or if anyone else wondered, this copy includes not only the Ultraviolet digital copy, but also an iTunes copy as well. I know I prefer iTunes over UV, so I hope this helps anyone on the fence due to that issue.

With a new director Francis Lawrence (I Am Legend), The Hunger Games: Catching Fire shifts its focus from the Battle Royale-like killing game to the tributes, or the participants of the game, themselves.

President Snow (Donald Sutherland) decides to hold the 75th Hunger Games, or the third Quarter Quell, and this time tributes are to be chosen from the existing winners of the game, regardless of age. President of the oppressive government knows what he is doing, and hires a new game master (Philip Seymour Hoffman). Now the symbol of peoples power, Katniss knows the game is no longer just about her and Peetas survival.

The first sequel (two more are in production) spends more time on describing the complicated relationships between the three characters Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence), Peeta Mellark (Josh Hutcherson) and Gale Hawthorne (Liam Hemsworth), as well as the psychological changes that Katniss as a reluctant heroine undergoes. That means that those who are looking for action may not like the way the story unfolds, which is pretty slow in the first sixty minutes. The pre-game section takes time, perhaps more than necessary.

One of the best things of the first sequel (two more are in production) is the new characters, especially the tributes played by Jena Malone, Amanda Plummer and Jeffrey Wright. Their unpredictable personalities are more interesting than the game itself.

As I said, there would be two more sequels coming in 2014 and 2015 respectively. Though there are some room for improvement, like its slow pace and some ineffective visual effects, the first sequel has started pretty good.

This movie is a bit darker that the first.  As most 2nd movies it is a transition piece.  Jennifer Lawrence continues to be one of the very bright spots in the Hollywood scene. She owns this movie and is great.

I don't understand why people could like those kind of movie. People killing people. Disgusting. This movie is bad, bad.

I am not a huge fan of the first installment of the franchise. The camera, environment, drama, characters. It was a whole big mess and the biggest problem was not setting up the big plot points that were going to appear in this movie and in the next two. But Catching Fire fixes all of those problems and mainly thanks to the new director in the helm.
The cast does such a GREAT job this time around, it's not even funny. The addition of new supporting characters complemented the story nicely. They weren't there just to be there, they were present for a reason, they had meaning. The acting in this is superb. Everybody adds emotion to their role and much needed it was. Believe it or not, Peeta was the only character worth liking in the first one because he was the only one with depth. But in this film, Katniss, Heymitch, the supporting cast and the other competitors, Primrose and Katniss' mother. Even Effie gets to have some type of emotion to the circumstances. The only downfall here is Gale which like in the first one, they don't do anything or give him anything to do in this one and as a result, his character feels flat.

The camera isn't in close up mode all the time which feels like a relief from the first one. Another thing is how the environment looked when in the Hunger Games and it looks incredible. These movies were supposed to be dark because they touch upon the theme of rebellion and survival and that is exactly what the director incorporated into this film. And for thank God that they finally showed something relative to mining in District 12. If you're a fan of the first one, buy this and watch it, it improves on so many levels. If you weren't a fan of the first movie, buy this and watch it, it improves on so many levels.
